reviewText:
I bought this game because the initial reviews were SO positive. I was super hyped to get it and actually had to struggle with Steam Support for one week due to my payment method screwing up. When I was finally able to play I was totally stoked. I didn't buy Rome II due to people complaining about it being unfinished and an unworthy sequel. When Attila was released, many reviews said it might not be worth the full price because it is very similar to Rome II, but it being the improved, more fluent version with a different setting. Since I didn't buy Rome II, I felt like I was on the good side buying this.

Well... Apart from the game being too slow, needing a lot of turns to achieve something (especially economically), the  campaign AI is what makes my stomach turn and my heart hurt. I loved Medieval II and the AI was obviously far from perfect, but this? This is a disaster!
Enemies that declare war on you don't show up in any way sometimes - leaving you stocking up your defences for no reason. Then again friendly states or trade partners trespass your borders without any notice, although the human player is so neatly informed that such an action might have diplomatic consequences. In this way, military access is basically worth nothing. Then, when they do not have a clear destination for some reason, they either end up marching to and fro on the campaign map until the cycle is broken through some outside force. If that's not what's happening, get used to the army doing the same sh*t for forever. When they do not move around, they simply raid any region they find themselves in; it is literally just as normal as trespassing without notice! No matter whether you are friend or foe, the right to raid seems impeccable. So get used to your allies or even vassals to raid your ♥♥♥ and cause economic and civic demise.
The other side to this is that enemies that DO actually invade you get stuck in that same action for years, leaving a fully stacked army for minimal effect.

What's more is that the coding for sea travel or landing on shore is completely messed up as well. I had two enemy factions from the British isle trying to invade me with two fully stacked armies each, both lead by their high king -  too bad their admirals were too intellectually challenged to get to a coast line where the army can actually leave the ships. And that did not end, they remained on sea until I was done playing this alpha version of a game.
Moreover, despite the fact that I love factions to be able to become a horde, abandon home and seek shelter in far away, possibly more fertile lands, everything described above concerning army movement on the campaign map also applies for hordes.

And yet, a special place in hell be reserved for the people making the AI raze EVERY F♥CKING SETTLEMENT THEY CONQUER. Literally, I have not seen more than maybe five times that a nearby enemy would actually take over a city. They either sack it, meaning looting goods and getting immediate pay off for their victory, which is the best thing for you to happen since you can keep the settlement and simply repair damaged buildings; or they turn to their favorite habit of razing and thus destroying everything you have raised and invested in in so many weary turns. After a while, you will find that half of all the settlements were razed, leaving them desolate, which in turn requires a ridiculously high amount of money to re-establish - not to mention all the money needed for more advanced buildings. Thus, re-settling in a desolate region is actually incredibly unrewarding and strategically silly.

I hope I could give you an idea as to how it feels playing this game right now. These are just the major flaws that drove me really mad, not mentioning the missing diversity between factions' units, buildings or simply their representatives (Western Roman Empire, Gauls, Brits, Roman and Western Roman Separatists have equally looking leaders; same goes for Eastern Roman Empire, Macedonia, Eastern Roman Separatists, Judea and possibly more, only played one campaign)...

reviewText:
Total War has improved drastically with Attila. While it definitely shares mechanical similarities to Rome 2, it honestly feels like a completely different game. Both games should be played independantly, and for different reasons.

Rome 2 was very much an empire builder where the goal was to get as big as possible, Attila is definitely more of a survival game.
Attila makes many improvements on Rome 2, such as obvious better visuals and improved anti-aliasing. Mechanically it is similar but the Campaign has many improvments including the Family Tree and more diplomacy options. These add to the complexity of the campaign gameplay. Battles are also much harder and have been reworked to be a bit more realistic. Units will route faster but will also return to the fight easier. Fatigue is also much more of an issue.

It has one main flaw, the lack of culture types. The game contains many factions from different parts of the known world, but we're missing Celtic, Slavic and Sarmatian units. Instead all Celts use Nordic units, Slavs use German units and Sarmatians use Hun units. It's a bit jarring and makes me miss the diversity of Rome 2, but I'm sure it'll improve in time with patches and DLC.

Overall, Attila is a fantastic game, but it isn't a replacement for Rome 2. Both games should be played and enjoyed for different reasons.

reviewText:
Certainly an improvement in most areas of Rome II. The graphics are impressive, and the battle mechanics are much more logical. They have fixed issues with archers and any ranged weapons being absurdly inaccurate to the point of not needing them. The new features allowing players to Raze cities is a good feature that certainly kicks dirt into your sworn enemies.

However, the AI still cheats. Small nations can spam units, seemly immune to the lack of food. Agents with one star will tear down your nine star general in a max size army assisted by a five star agent of your own (Apparently it's statistically possible for enemy agents to succeed a 10% chance 8 times out of 10). Clearly from the unit rosters the Nations that you are intended to play to get the full Grand campaign experience are either the Huns, or either Roman nations (With Northern kingdoms added for extra flavour if you don't want to tackle the Huns). Except the Roman nations are seemly doomed to fail no matter how hard you try. But, that's due to unbalanced gameplay, rather then intended diffculty.

Diplomacy may as well not exist. Usually I gather trade partners and allies at the start, yet just by advancing technology, and generally trying to use the features of the game you gain an unavoidable penalty, leaving the entire map against you. The only Nations I have on my side, leaving the majority at war with me are Nations I subjugated. AI doesn't really attempt realism at all. As I played with the Eastern Roman empire I had four stacks of Hunic armies sail directly from Spain, after ending the Western Empire, cross the full length of the Mediterrean Ocean with armies of Horse archers on ships, to deposit next to Alexandria the second I left to attempt a defense against no less then eight armies from the Sassanid Empire.

The Grand campaign seems to be following a programmed script, with events like declarations of war happening regardless of any effort you make. After the Barbarian Kingdoms Raze around 60% of the map, leaving a hard bill of 20000 currency to rebuild each of them from scratch, and the major kingdoms following predetermined orders to annihilate you, you will find the great empire you start with, over twenty cities, suffering from no food and constant rebellions, with a hot side of bankruptancy. You armies suffer attrition to such a degree that a full stack will have 10 people in each unit, with no hint of replenishment in sight.

In summary, if you want to play exactly as history occured, with the failure of the Roman empire (regardless of your efforts), and you like cheating AI that provides an artificial challenge, then buy this game. I don't recomend this game mostly because the Grand campaign is more like a long term scenario, instead of the real total war experience.

reviewText:
I have been playing Total War games since the original Shogun, and I have enjoyed every single one immensely. I can also say that Atilla is still just as fun and continues to bring in innovations to the Total War formula (hoards, razing and sacking without having to occupy, liberating dead factions, etc). The AI is also better, providing more of a challenge in battle and less unpredictability in diplomacy. No longer do I worry about friendly factions suddenly turning on me for no reason.

So all in all Atilla is a good game that I would recommend you play.

HOWEVER: The only problem I have with it, is SEGAs pricing decisions, mainly to restrict content on first release that you must pay extra to unlock. Now I’m completely fine with developers continuing to release expansions for additional cost after they’ve released the game, as they obviously cost money to develop. However what offends me is selling a game and then deliberately withholding content for those not willing to pay a premium.

As far as i’m concerned, content that is in the initial release should be FULLY available to anyone who purchases the game. This is not something that has taken extra resources to develop, as you still play against the viking and celt factions. This is just a money grabbing scheme by SAGA to increase their profits.

If such factions genuinely would have cost enough to develop to effect the price of the final product, just sell the game at a marginally higher price if you must.

I fear that this is part of an unfortunate trend in content limiting pricing policies. For example in Rome II, separate Greek factions were available with the release game, only to those who have pre-ordered. As well as another example of restricted content, it also disincentivizes a company to create a good game, so long as they can just market it well and generate hype to get enough orders up front. If the game turns out to be bad, they’ve already made their money.

I can see how a small company may need pre-orders to generate some cash up front to help with development, or for high street shops so they can gage the number of hard copies to order in to avoid disappointment. But for a large company like SEGA on a digital platform there is no reason the require pre-orders. Collectables, development info, glossy maps/booklets, these are the sort of things that fans should get from pre-orders, not exclusive content that was created for the game in the first place.

In summary, people play hundreds and hundreds of hours on these games and, I believe, would be happy to pay slightly more for a good quality, full game as we would still be getting our money's worth compared to the average play time of an action game in the same price bracket.

What I disagree with is not the price of the restricted content, but the principle

reviewText:
At first when I started playing Total War: Attila, I could barley hang on to it. As soon as I began playing, the game made me sick. Even with a good computer set up, I still have trouble running this game in big battles on high quality. I wouldn't recommend this Total War game to someone who has a less than average PC, and loves graphics.

The AI in the game is still muffed up. There would be beach city battles that I would be defending and there is a high chance I will have to spend the sixty minutes waiting for the game to end, all because the AI refused to beach a unit.
The AI always magically knows where you are in the campaign, so there wont be much of a point in using guarilla warfare/ambush stance.
The auto-battle mechanic in the campaign is awful, in which I may have better tier/trained units than the enemy, who usually use tier 1 spearmen, but they magically still have the edge in winning the battle. This is bad as well because your allies are usually out numbered. Eventually it turns into a numbers game. Who can throw around the most troops wins. Not who has the best strategy.
Your AI ally always makes ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥ decisions. For instance, I was the WRE and my ally, the ERE, was mainly in South Africa. This was somewhat later in the game. I sent a general and his army to help stop the Eastern invaders from pushing into South Africa. The point of no return was Alexandria, the spot we had to defend. Once my army got there, I place them in fortified stance. Everything was going smooth till the Eastern invaders arrived, immedialey the ERE AI took off from the defence leaving me to defend their own city by myself. If the ERE AI army was there, we would have easily beaten the Eastern Invaders back, but no, we got overran.

I still have much to go on about. The game is addicting for what ever reason, and somehow I found it more interesting and fun to play versus Total War, Rome 2. The darker theme and setting in which the apocalypse is taking in due to Attila's reign across Europe.
You have a family tree and potential diplomatic marriage to work on, which can be helpful and fun to roleplay with.
Thankfully, the biggest and main reason I play total war is its mods. Without steam workshop I probably would never place Total War Attila. Radious makes the campaign fun to play as you can gain much better stats. Not only that, but Radious' unit mod finally brings diversity, which the vanilla units lacked.

Above all, without mods and steam workshop. I would NEVER play Total War Atilla.
With Steam Workshop, well from the hours I spend on it, you can tell for yourself.

reviewText: This game, in terms of its mechanics and gameplay, is technically the best total war game in my eyes. With fantastic additions to the strategic mechanics such as the new siege system where cities take damage every turn you're besieging them, the disease and sanitation system, the most welcome return of family trees and engaging political intrigue, it is by far the most complex and thus the most satisfying total war game to date.\n\nBUT... and there's a big but; the game is woefully unoptimized in tactical battles, the system requirements, minimum and recommended, are not representative of what you actually need at all. It makes it the most frustrating total war game to play for me, on the one hand you have the best strategic layer ever and technically the best tactical gameplay, but the tactical half is just ruined by insufficient optimization. After Rome 2 Emperor Edition I was highly anticipating Attila also getting the same treatment optimization-wise. It didn't happen. Right after they pushed out the last set of DLC, they moved right on to making Total War: Warhammer. So, much like Empire Total War, this leaves me with a bitter taste in my mouth when I play it, knowing it has been abandoned before all the issues have been ironed out. No amount of excuses about how they were future proofing" the game will satisfy me

reviewText:
~Written 6 days after the game has come out for future reference~

Positives:
1) The battle AI seems generally improved. They flank with cavalry, go into spaced formation when shot at and have much better pathfinding. Also, they use their abilities more now.
2) Politics has been reworked and now is quite in depth, though is slightly confusing at times. Characters can perform tasks such as looking for a wife or stealing funds.
3) Unit upgrades have been added to all factions instead of just Rome from Rome II. Through tech your weak levy unit can eventually turn into quite decent units.
4) The new siege mechanics of doing fire damage to inflict debuffs or maintaining seige for long enough to open holes in the enemy walls without having to have any seige equipment is useful and interesting, meaning you no linger have to seige them out for the whole 12 turns but can wait 7 and then swarm through the gap that opened up.

Neutral:
1) Morale seems either too powerful or too weak depending on the situation. Units rout very easily now, which on itself isn't bad, but by manipulating it you can really bully the AI. It rarely defends its general, and killing the general now seems to give a HUGE penalty to morale, so much so that I've seen entire stacks rout once their general dies. Helpful when attacking the AI, but it can be silly sometimes when your own army runs away despite still having full numbers because some unit fired a whistling arrow" at you.
2) Razing and sacking is an interesting mechanic which I want to like

reviewText:
People tear this game apart because of the rather gross habit Creative Assembly has of releasing overpriced DLC with a lack of content. Now I'm not about to say that they are wrong or that you shouldn't tear this game apart for that. However I am going to say that this is by far one of the most detailed and fantastic Total War games I have ever played.

Having just gotten out of Rome 2 and prior to that Shogun 2 Fall of the Samurai with over 700 hours of gameplay between them I wanted a new experience and bought this game on the Lunar New Year sale of 2016 for a whooping $11.24, plus all the DLC for a total of $33.72 USD. Let me be clear this is probably the only way you should buy this game with the DLC, the base game has plenty to keep you interested but the DLC when it is not on sale is ridiculously over priced totalling $109.92 or an even more ridiculous $155.45 AUD.

In short, buy this game when it's on sale.

Now looking past that this game is amazing, in terms of graphics it's engaging, violent and looks very alive and real. You also get introduced to a whole new level of faction control, a lot of common Total War mechanics like food, religion, your faction's generals and/or nobles as well as your city's infastructure have been revamped to include new levels of detail and challenges, pay special attention to what your religion offers you it can be important.

Then there is the 'horde' mechanic wherein you can disband all your settlements and become a fully migratory faction which offers you the benefits of both a city, with a slightly limited recruitment roster, and the mobility of an army.

Overall this game offers exceptional detail and of all the Total War games the by far best empire management gameplay; it is absolutely fun, the DLC is just too expensive.

Get Age of Charlemagne though, it's amazing.

reviewText:
This game is a pure mission pack sequel.
What's ridiculous is the fact that many aspects of the game are blatantly WORSE than in Rome 2: Emperor Edition.

They actually made an enhanced edition for Rome 2 that fixed almost everything wrong with it, and now... This. It will not improve, because they just announced Total War: Warhammer.

Unit control AI is RIDICULOUS now. It fails at pathfinding when you send in more than one unit at a time. Sieges are thus made obnoxiously hard.

I appreciate  the fact that the grand strategy elements are a solid improvement over Rome 2's... But the AI in battle mode is blatantly worse than what they offered with Rome 2 Emperor Edition, and makes the game nigh-unplayable. I've stopped playing it, in fact, and will be getting back to Rome 2, despite the fact that the Horde mechanics actually make playing an underdog fun (In Grand Strategy mode)

Also, CA seriously underinvested in rosters. All of the breakaway factions look EXACTLY like their parent faction. Not only historically ludicrous, but also a blatant cashgrab. There are NO possible breakaway factions from the middle east. None whatsoever. You can't even liberate multiple settlements in a region belonging to a breakaway faction if you want to build up a strong ally. You didn't even offer us Arab factions as DLC.

So... Can't liberate the Graeco-Bactrians or Kushans from the Afrighids. Can't find a bunch of Greeks in the Sassanid Empire to put in charge of a renewed Seleucid Empire. And, to put salt in an already gaping wound, it wouldn't make any point, because all of the minor factions in the game are the same as the major factions.

All of the DLC is... Meaningless. There's no point to playing this game if you have Rome 2: Emperor Edition. None whatsoever. Get that instead. Despite its flaws, it's a better game with higher production values. I can't believe I paid full price for this piece of *ahem*.

Please, someone, kickstart a game that offers a better experience than this. I don't mind bad graphics, I really don't. What I do mind is the fact that Attila: Total War is nothing but a dress rehearsal that we, the dwindling fanbase of Total War, had to pay a pretty penny for, when it, like Rome 2: Emperor Edition, ought to have been made available for free or at least at a reduced price, as a concession to long-suffering fans who honestly wanted a game that would be good at launch and improve over time.

I will not be buying Total War: Warhammer at launch. Not by a long shot. I will wait for at least a year before buying it, so  there will at least be proper AI mods and whatnot. This game is, like Rome 2 at launch, a black stain on the reputation of Creative Assembly. It's a travesty, and I cannot for the life of me imagine what CA thought when they released this game. Was it because they were pressured by Sega?

You screwed us over, CA, and it's pretty clear you're going to drop the ball pretty quickly, since this is a B-release. It was never intended to have the production values of a Rome or Medieval game. To make us pay full price for this travesty at launch was an insult to your fanbase, and you should probably switch publishers or self-publish. You've grown too big, too complacent. It's time to dial back and focus on delivering a game fans want to play.

reviewText:
I've only played a little bit so far, but I can confidently say I'm liking what I've seen so far. Overall, the game is better than Rome 2 in my honest opinion.

Instead of giving an arbitrary rating, I'm going to go into detail as to what I like and do not like throughout this review. If you're not interested in reading some blocks of text talking about the new features, you can skip to the end of this review and find a simple TL;DR section.

I've been trying out the Nomad mechanics, which work fairly well - you own nothing beyond your armies, which act as cities themselves when 'set up' using a stance like fortify in the previous games. Nomadic 'cities' are more restricted economically and have a lack of defenses (none at all, if you get attacked while set up it'll be fought like any normal staged field battle).

Beyond the Nomad mechanics, the game also appears to be harder than Rome 2. Better units will turn the tide of battle if used correctly, but even veteran soldiers can be crushed by peasants if you're unprepared. Combat is conisderably faster paced, making the slow down time and pause buttons more crucial for the more casual tacticians - if you don't know what you're doing, or miss even a small detail, you can watch as even the most stable stratergies go out of the window when troops manage to flank or break through your lines.

The family tree has been implemented nicely, basically in the same way as the previous games with better UI in my opinion. Long awaited in my eyes, I'm more than happy to see it back in the total war series, and not even a half-baked feature at that.

The UI has also been overhauled. I like the changes overall - initially a little off-putting because some stuff had been completely relocated but something

Oh, and then the desolation mechanic. I'm loving it - I burnt every city I passed by to the ground as I marched south as Hunnic armies chased me - the huns are somewhat unrelenting, something I feel the need to praise, as they chased me all the way into the mediterranean sea, where I found refugee on Krete - the huns apparently do not like water, and thus did not pursue. Many of the cities are still abandoned, years later, though the ERE has recovered some of them, rebuilding cities from the ruins.

The Huns can be rather... Dangerous. In my first campain, they've literally destroyed most of Europe and even most of North Africa in the process of chasing my Nomadic people from the Balkans all the way to Africa.

Sadly the doesn't have a great variety of playable factions. This is somewhat bad news as far as I'm concerned, especially after having seen the pre-order faction, Vikings, having a price tag of 10 bucks - if you buy this game and then get the DLC outside of any sales, you should expect to pay through the nose.

TL;DR

The Game adds a bunch of nicely integrated features that are far from half-baked. I'd argue this game is nothing more than a standalone expansion and the price is potentially a little steep (especially with the lack of factions), so unless you've got money burning a hole in your pocket, I'd suggest waiting for a sale - beyond that, I'd recommend it to any Total War fan.

EDIT:
18 hours of gameplay later...

Factions. Oh dear. Overall, they failed to make the factions completely unique; most of the factions feature a generic 'Germanic' unit tree, with very few (usually a handful) if any unique factional units.

That isn't something I think is quite so great, but it *should* hopefully get fixed by players via modding. Sorta sad to see the devs take such a shortcut, but at least with modding it isn't going to be a permanent issue (but one people should be aware of prior to any substantial release of mods or changes made by the devs).

P.S. Thanks for the game Hirovard! ;)

What gets me is that every faction under the sun gets it when really, only the ERE and maybe the WRE should get access to it. Please CA: Fix Greek Fire. It's literally half the reason I picked the ERE at game start and I find out 30 turns in that anyone can use it. Talk about a downer.

I also understand that you're probably using the name because most people don't realize that Byzantium and Rome are one and the same, but it's a little jarring and immersion-breaking seeing Byzantine Marines in a Dromon in the same fleet as Roman Marines in a Liburnian. Eastern Roman works just as well and doesn't kill my immersion. I payed 45 U.S. Dollars basically to play Byzantium (And a smattering of Persia/Franks) and you guys can't even get that much completely right.

Technology researching is pretty much exactly the same as it was in Shogun II and Rome II, so no quibbles on that department.

Also, most of the flags are completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. So ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that I have to say it twice.

There's probably some stuff I missed in this review, but there's my 2 cents at any rate.

Pizza-Sempai out.

reviewText:
I praised TW:Rome 2 for being a good game overall and a very easy entry into the series, but this game is what it should have been. Playing Total War: Attila on easy feels like Rome 2 does on hard. If you are deciding between the two games, Attila is better, Rome 2 is easier and mostly stripped down with worse balance (Pikemen FTW).

TW:A Looks better, is better balanced, has better internal politics, more rational diplomacy, more diversity between factions, the horde game mechanic, religions that give different benefits vs. unchangable cultures of Rome 2, and much more thinking-intensive situations as well. One wrong move and your faction could be totally obliterated before you even reach the point where you can stand up to the more belligerent foes.

So, where are the problems? Yes..DLC, but that isn't technically a gameplay issue that affects the game very heavily. The AI is much more of a problem, having the three modes of: brilliance, stupidity, and cheating. When the AI cheats it is just as bad as in Rome 2 and the AI can evicerate your full army with 4 units if you autoresolve, but that can be avoided by playing a battle (which is always better anyway).

Overall: 8/10 - The game itself is fine and more of everything than Rome 2, lots of mods available, but quite a bit of overpriced DLC.

reviewText:
I want to start by saying, that despite buying this game with incredible skepticism, this turned out to be the most fun  I have ever had in a grand strategy game.  This game returns to the roots of the original Total War, and makes more inovations to the series and RTS genre than any other game in the Total War Series.

Campaign
-----------
+ Weather is dynamic and strong winters have the potential to wipe out entire armies
+ Great Migrant and Barbarian Horde factions roam the map sacking settlements and razing entire provinces
+ Ships and Land Units travel realistically. The powerful viking navies will be restricted to travel through currents
+ Britain is now a 4 way warzone between Vikings, Celts, Romans, and Barbarian Tribes
+ Legendary Challenges trying to set up new kingdoms over a devastated Europe (by the time Atilla takes power in 422 over 100 regions will be razed and uninhabitable)
+ Moderate sized factions can produce a dozen armies over time
+ A new war economy allows any faction to make 100,000's quickly solely off of warfare alone
+ Sacking cities yields nearly double the gold it did in Rome II, with perks allowing even greater loot
+ You can now conscript captives into your armies after a battle to replenish numbers
+ After a battle, you can sell captives back to their faction for money
+ Integrity system has a major role on how your armies and legions operate in foreign lands. They are more likely to do dishonarable things, like hold off on giving you loot and raiding lands, if you let their integrity fall to low
+ You can decimate legions in order to restore integrity
+ The map has been extended to include more parts of modern day Russia
+ As civilization begins to fall, new factions will quickly arise such as Britain, Gaul, Pontus, Macedonia, Illyria, ect.
+ Armies, Cities, and Characters can be renamed. For example, you can take Constantinople and rename it Byzantium
+ Capitals now exist which support certain buildings exclusive to the province
+ New Architecture can be found on the map including the wall seperating the Picts from civilized Britain
+ Land fertility FINALLY exists. Not all land produces the same amount of crops
+ Barbarian societies do not have military chains. Instead, regular building chains allow unit recruitment

- They took away northern Afghanistan from the campaign map (for those who want to play as Indo-Greeks)
- It is very difficult to create a trade powerhouse, unlike other Total War games
- Resources have less strategic importance, mostly as a result of the decline of trading
- The devastation of the campaign map, combined with the extremely high costs of colonization, makes expansion drudgingly slow.

Unique Campaign Battlefields
--------------------------------
+ Certain cities, fields, towns, and ports are custom designed by CA and can't be encountered twice on the campaign map (see below)
* The Nile
* The Tiber
* Black Sea (specific area)
* Cap Bon (specific area)
* Mediterannian (specific area)
* Abarsharar
* Ancyra
* Caesaria Euesabia
* Casurgis
* Constantinople
* Corduba
* Ctesiphon
* Edessa
* Kath
* Londinum
* Ravenna
* Roma
* Tuessis
* Abursis
* Vesontio
* Zafar
* Alia Capitonia
* Asturica
* Belz
* Domavia
* Harev
* Hira
* Iconium
* Payttakaran
* Petrodava
* Siscia
* Turonum
* Virunum
* 5 different unique land battles which can be encountered on the map
* 8 different unique port cities (cannot access the list)

+ The unique campaign battlefield modification will likely inspire mods for the other cities not designed by CA

- The price to pay for all these unique cities and towns is that generic city maps off the list reoccur more often than Rome II

Battle
-------
+ Units have more abilities and formations
+ Units now spread out during engagements and pick targets, reminescient of the duels that took place in Shogun
+ Cities and Towns can be completely destroyed and devastated during the course of a battle
+ Defensive Positions now exist in sieges which can yield negative effects on the enemy if taken
+ Barricades now exist in town and city battles
+ Less units than Rome II, but they are more specialized and unique
+ Second tier units no longer look like lazy reskins
+ Civilians occupy battlefields. They will either skirmish your troops, run for safety, or huddle up to be slaughtered
+ Artillery Barges with high ammunition allow you to devastate any coastal city with zero loss of life (in retrospect this can annoy some people)
+ Pikes and spears are no longer unrealistically OP against melee troops
+ Melee troops will fall back naturally on your spear units without having to order them to do so
+ Fear and Morale has a greater impact on the course of a battle than the actual fighting. Vikings and Huns can rout entire legions by massive use of fire and shock tactics
+ While exploiting defensive formations is still possible, a concentrated force can break a tightly compact formation without losing 90% of the army. This is the greatest improvement of the game.
+ While minor factions can still produce hordes, the new realistic unit stats make it so a  levy is not balanced with a Roman cohor.
+ The alliance setting will color enemies based on their allegiance as either a player, ally, or enemy
+ Kill animations!

- The morale effects of devasting a city during battle are slightly OP. An elite unit with high morale will lose 1/3 of his attack and defense if the city is in ruins.
- The only units which can defend a barricade are archers. Spears are incapable of stabbing units horded around the fortification
- The defenses in siege battles are oddly positioned. There are archer towers in the most vunerable places, and never near the town hall, capitol, or millitary camps where it is most defensible.
- Combat could still use some work in areas. Without mods, many units will still kill by swinging their sword into the air.
- It would be nice if you had some decent pike units to counter the Steppe tribes. Pikes are not overpowered in this game, but I still believe their abscense is a result of complaints from Rome II.

Religion
---------
+ There are many new religions such as Latin Christianity, Greek Christianity, Graeco-Roman Paganism, Germanic Paganism, Celtic Paganism, Zoroasteranism, Manachiesm, and Tengri.
+ Each religion has its own chain of buildings
+ Priest units are back
+ When 30% of your population worships a non-state religion, you can convert to that religion

- There is no incentive to be a certain religion besides reducing discontent and improving relationships, since most building chains operate with the same rewards

Political System
-----------------
+ There are now three new political meters. Dominion, Control, and Power.
+ Dominion is the loyalty and control you have over your statesman, generals, and office holders
+ Control is your popularity and influence in the senate or tribal council
+ Power is the combination of your dominion and control. Being to weak will cause internal factions to try and rise up the ranks, while being to powerful will cause resentment and campaign penalties

+ Intrique returns greater than ever. Every character in your faction, which is usually around 40 midgame, has a certain amount of loyalty, influence, and ambitionb. Unloyal characters will try to defect from your faction, or work against you on the political scene. Influence is a currency system which grows based on a characters office, and allows them to commit intriques. Characters with high gravitas, which represents power, are more ambitious, and will try to cheat their way into office, or even the throne.

+ The new intriques include
* Assasination
* Secure Loyalty
* Arrange Marriage
* Divorce
* Seek Wife
* Diminish Popularity
* Adopt
* Become Retainer
* Embezzle Funds
* Gather Support

Much, much better.

From top to bottom Attila's release has been a vast improvement from Rome 2's (which despite a horrible release turned out to be a decent game, so image where Attila will be in the final version).

Some cons:
Campaign ai tends to drift between the aggresiveness of Alexander the Great and the stupidity Peter Griffen.

Many Factions are just copies of each other.

reviewText:
So after the catastrophe that was the release of Rome 2 everyones wanting to know if this is better. Well, I think getting run over is better than Rome 2's release, so obviously it is better. Rome 2 did get fixed up but it took a hell of a long time to get it right. But yes, this is better than Rome 2.

THE GOOD:

In fact, the campaign is absolutely fantastic, it's got the best atmosphere of any total war game I've played, obviously I am likely to edit this review as I sink more hours into the game, so far my first campaign as the Geats (a DLC Viking faction) has been enjoyable, sailing around, plundering wealthy coastal settlements and generally not giving a f*ck (stealing money, send it to strengthen my capital and smoke weed everyday).

However, I dabbled a little bit with the other factions campaigns and there is a so much diversity in the general feel of each group of factions. You can feel playing as the Romans that their days are numbered and it's damage control from the get go, the  Sassanids are the new big power and are ready to rise up and become a dominant force and replace the old, frail empires in the west. The barbarian tribes have a fight for survival, scrabbling to hold their lands against the behemoths that are both Roman Empires, but the threat of hordes coming and destroying your lands and your people is ever constant, so you always have a lot to think about. The hordes are well, hordes. You are what keeps the 'civilised' people awake at night, especially as the Huns who can't settle, only loot and raze.

Sieges are an absolute delight as well, the defenders being able to craft barricades in the street really adds another dimension, the fire spreading throughout the city is great to watch, while the defeneders have the strategic advantage behind their walls and barricades, fire weakens their stats and morale, creating a better balance of gameplay. Each main faction looks great as well, this belongs in the bad section but since Im already talking about it I should mention that some of the unplayable barbarian factions are too similar, there's absolutely nothing to distinguish them from each other apart from their faction sigil. However the Roman soldiers look great, a far cry from the glorious looking legionaires you had in Rome 2, these legionaries are much uglier and darker (but in a good way).

The family tree is a welcome return, however it doesn't cast off everything that Rome 2 implemented, taking some of the good things like influence and political occurences. What was a disorganised mess, but a good idea in rome 2 has now been refined to something which is much easier to get to grips with.

THE BAD:

Mainly technical, but the one gameplay flaw I can spot right now is the razing mechanic, while it is a great thing they've put in the game, once you raze a settlement, the land in that province is now classed as 'desolate' and inhospitable. This certainly is an interesting mechanic though I fear that as a campaign progresses there is a danger of too many places becoming 'desolate' and there being not enough towns and cities to take. This is yet to be seen of course but it seems all too likely a problem.

Time between turns is unforgivably long, I've gone and made a nice brew (cuppa tea for you Americans) in the time it takes for turns to finish. Not to mention loading times for battles are huge. Once it gets going, its great, but have a book with you to read between turns, perhaps an encyclopedia on Roman history?

Graphics optimisation is once again, poor. I can run Rome 2 fairly well at medium-high settings but it's very difficult to run this game anything higher than low settings. This wouldn't have bothered me so much if there was an increase in visual quality but it all looks the same as Rome 2, albeit a bit more brown, dark and gritty. For so little difference in visuals yet a huge decrease in performance it really is an irritating situation. Check your specs before going into it to make sure you're able to run it well as on low settings it does look pretty pants.

Technical issues aside, the game has fantastic gameplay mechanics and is a bloody good job by CA.

So far I'd give this an 8/10, great work.

reviewText:
I have played every single total war game ever, I started shogun 1 when I was 4 years old. I have a minimum of 10 hours on games like empire... and hundreds and hundreds of hours on games I really enjoyed, like Shogun II and Medieval II (and Rome II after the Emperor Edition...) So obviously I have had a lot of experience with the games. But good as those games were, they have nothing on Attila. Now, I find it a bit of a stretch to say it is the best total war game yet, but if it isn't, then what is? Medieval II was great, but it's time is past. The graphics are almost painful to play with in this age where technology is so advanced. Attila is just a step forward in so many directions, it's ridiculous. The graphics are slightly better than Rome II, and certainly better than any other TW game. The campaign mechanics are phenomenal, they bring all the good parts of past campaigns back, and add in new, better parts. For example, the horde mechanic is SO fun to play as. You can lay waste to the empires, and there is a small chance the nation will be able to deal with you as they have many problems on their hands. However, they are still a force to be reckoned with and you'd better run if they come your way.
Also, the battle mechanics are amazing! the seiges are AWESOME and each city has stellar work put in to it to make it unique, ending the problem in Rome II how every city in a district looked the same, making defensive seiges very, VERY boring. But even the random cities in Attila have been changed. Also, Attila has finally dealt with a problem in all tw games... the damaging affects of the battle on the terrain. Now, everything you do can affect the battlefield; from accidentally (or purposefully) burning down a forest to scorching the earth with your catapults. No other Tw game has come even close to this (I'm not counting Rome II's pathetic attempt where trees with brun for a couple seconds then fizzle out).
There are a few problems, however; things they removed that I didn't appreciate. For some reason CA thought it would be a good idea to remove the bar at the end of a battle that showed you how many kills you got. This is not a problem in 1v1, but in 2+v2+ games, especially multiplayer, it removes a sense of achievement; that you cant figure out who had the most kills. CA, if you are reading this, PLEASE ADD IT BACK IN!!! Also a minor problem, they removed the function to duplicate units in custom battle. This is a really small problem however, and the amount of Pro's in the game overwhelm the small problems I have. GREAT JOB CA!!! I think this is hands down an amazing game and I recomend you buy it.

-Arthur Wellesley, The Duke of Wellington

reviewText:
Having played every single Total war title and add-on to date this is my least favourite by a large margin, and is the first in the series I have uninstalled after only a few hours, as I simply cannot be bothered with it.

The sacking mechanic is asinine, the ability to sack an entire region with a single click in a single turn laying waste to everything over hundreds of square miles. Unit balance is all over the place, with many countries listed as normal difficulty, near impossible to play. Take the latest dlc for the Celts, they are largely useless against the western roman troops who are at this point supposed to be in trouble, but who can still field multiple full stacks seemingly out of nowhere. Unless of course you are playing as the Western Roman Empire them then you are scratching for troops at every turn to defend against the ai. The politics are a waste of time no one will accept peace unless they are on the brink of destruction, likewise trying to set up trade is near pointless unless the target nation is already kissing your ♥♥♥♥. Your own government, happy one-minute, are on the verge of civil war the next.

The entire thing is dull and ill-conceived, and I have not even touched on the recent policy of shoving three dlc out the door before the ink on our receipts is dry.

Frankly, I would rather have paid to have Rome II’s graphics engine upgraded with Attila’s.

reviewText:
Well guys i have been getting many questions from friends so here is my early review on Total War: ATTILA .



Unlike past total war games ATTILA really puts a big focus on the roaming nations like the Visogoths, Huns, Osogaths, etc. This is no exspansion of Rome 2: Total War. Personally i prefer ATTILA over Rome 2 for many reasons. Some of those reasons is that the cinematics are back! Good Mideval 2 Total War cinematics that are back along with the family tree that has been missing for some time.


Politics have exploded in this game. Feels much more like Crusaders Kings 2 politics with the internal family and then the other nobles. Marriages now are important in that they secure alliances which bonds neighbors. Most of all the politics is something actually needed to be kept in order unless if you want to lose your control after a couple turns.


Battles do feel very different, i will not lie some issues are abroad. Morale seems to be a factor which needs to be worked upon in my view. Battles do not last a few minutes anymore and can actually stretch for a long time. The various maps in which you play on are countless and will not stay the same for each playthrough.


Sieges are completely new. Actual siege towers and ladders needing to be used! I know right! Unlike ATTILA's predecessor, sieges are very hard now and the walls make a huge difference. Your archers will barely even scratch those on the wall until you smash them down using Onagers or some other siege equipment.


So after reading all this you may guess i reccomend right? Well i do and i don't. This game at its current state is very difficult and the AI is too good for new guys to just hop in. For gameplay? Yes i do reccomend if you enjoy a good strategy game which now has so many new features.



Well thanks guys for asking and here is my insight for you all.

reviewText: Creative Assembly isn’t being greedy. Not one bit. They are just accurately reflecting the cutthroat reality of dark age business. Attila ravaged Europe, and 1600 years later, CA ravaged my wallet.\n\nAllow me to explain why it’s fitting that Creative Assembly chose the era of Attila for their latest installment of the Total War series. After years of painstaking historical research, I have come to the conclusion that CA based their pricing model on common dark age business practices. There is a tale, for instance, of High King Schwarzenegger, a Gothic monarch of the Conan tribe, who purchased a sword but only received a hilt. When the king complained about the hilt that he paid full price for, the smith told him that blades were sold separately and that if the king wanted a scabbard, that too would require another purchase. reviewText:
Its a pretty simple comparison to other Total War titles, some of the differences however are terrible.

- Hordes; the ability for entire civs to pack up and travel across the map to distance from hostile zones or set up in more favourable locations is an amazing idea, however the start of hordes within/close to settled nations with such an incredible numbers advantage is frustrating getting chain ransacked through the start of the game.

- Spotting/FOW/LOS; This addition while in previous games was an option, in this game is rediculous. Its not just that you can't spot enemy forces in cover, but that without terrible scout units you end up with the enemy not being visible until they are 20-30 meters in front of your troops in open terrain, or until you're already being shot at from hills/walls.

- Influence/Control; Good idea, poorly executed. It can be aboslute struggle if you want to maintain loyalty, integrity, higher influence than rivals, and if completely neglected, doesn't affect the overall game.

- DLCs released within 2 weeks of game release? GTFOH, Squeezing the teet for every drop. These are all factions that should have been included with the game release - and now that theres new units ect that are released with it means even if you dont want to play those factions you still need to purchase them just so you get to play with ungimped nations. Disgusting abuse of the gamers which is soft coming from a guy who thought $3 for 'Blood' in a video game was the most idiotic thing ever.

- Lack of unit diversity; while the vast number of factions (I think campaign starts with almost 60) is great, the unit diversity is weak for most factions. Vikings a 'dlc' faction has only a handful of unique unit types(everyone has around the same spearmen/melee/calvary which are parallelly upgraded through the tech tree). While there are 60 factions there's only around 6 base unit rosters (Roman - African/Middleastern - Nomadic - Germanic - Nordic - Barbarian.

- Graphics; despite the mixed reviews I think they are reasonably solid, most reviewers are right though, there has been a lack of improvement in the last 4 years since Shogun 2 and frame issues even with the highest end cards is a little overboard (running 2x GTX 970s)

- Unit Fatigue; straight up needs a change, units cannot sprint for very long at all before they are tired, you can get though 50 meters and they're winded/tired which with the short and unrealistic spotting range makes manuvering for a hun calvary charge that just 'pops up' in that empty grassland 20 meters from your troops a huge disadvantage.

All in all its still a solid game, with some pros and alot of cons compared to former releases. The cons some of which I hope will be changed by mods very soon. I definitely dont think the Total War series is going in the right direction, having played every single total war release since the Kenshins of S:TW. These DLC's, lack of effort into creative story or an interest in changing to a new venue or engine makes it all feel lazy and more and more like TW is going down a cash grab track instead of releasing quality products the way it did with the original Rome TW and Shogun 2. Both titles were in their time revolutionary strategy releases.

The multiple transactions for factions/blood ect that should be apart of the game to begin with is really driving me away from this publisher. TWO PURCHASABLE DLC WITHIN TWO WEEKS OF RELASES MEANS THAT CONTENT SHOULDVE BEEN A PART OF THE GAME.

reviewText:
*This is not a review about the contents of Total War: ATTILA, this is a review of the current state of the game*

Total War: ATTILA is an improved version of Total War: Rome II. It boasts better gameplay mechanics, a 'smarter' AI, a more immersive campaign, and better graphics. However, the  game still contains quite some bugs, especially when it comes to multiplayer stability. Bugs which were originally included in Rome II (but were fixed later on) suddenly make a reappearance in ATTILA. Examples include: The game crashing after a NPC initiates a battle, sound cutting off, leaving you with nothing but sillence, or desyncs (especially the desyncs).
I've played Rome II for 380 hours, which does not quallify me as a master strategist. However, I did experience the whole 'broken launch', and all the patches afterwards. Rome II has come a long way since its launch, with the final Emperor's Edition being excellently playable. I find it dissapointing to see these long patched bugs reappear in ATTILA. Let's be serious here, a (real time strategy) game shouldn't crash whenever an enemy attacks you.

Gamebreaking or not, let's keep the bugs on the sideline here, and move on to the AI.
In the Total War series the AI is a large, if not crucial part of the game, with the campaign consisting almost entirely out of computer controlled factions. I am aware of the fact that it is nearly impossible to make an AI truly sophisticated, although Shogun II came pretty far, but the AI in ATTILA seems to have lowered the standards even more by its ridiculous obsession over barricades.
Let be support this statement with an example: Whenever you deploy a barricade in a settlement, and the AI comes near it, the AI will go full ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in its attempt to destroy the barricade. This can be incredibly useful, because it gives you some time to reposition your units, but it is NOT (really? not?) what a 'master strategist AI' should do.
The AI still seems to favor suicide charges over camping, which was probably coded to prevent the notorious 'hillcamping' from Shogun II. I will give credits to the campaign AI however, as they really manage to f*ck me up the ♥♥♥♥.

The game also has some performance issues, mainly when it comes to the graphics side.
I know, I know, this game is designed for future GPU's"

When you remove all these ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bugs

reviewText:
I'm really glad that Attila (as well as the substantive expansion packs, which are really totally different games using the same engine) is a good game. I say this as someone who finished Rome 2 out of sheer spite, pouring 150 hours into hate-beating the sequel to my favorite game of all time. This looks like Rome 2. It even has DLC like Rome 2. But the fundamental game is tighter and more compelling. I WANTED to play it.

Is it Rome 1 or Shogun 2? No, it's not. It's still kind of sprawling, and lacks the focus of these high points.
Is it possible to win a siege defense by sitting out at bay for half the battle, then hiding in trees with a single unit while the AI ♥♥♥♥♥ its pants? Sure. But CA at least TRIED to fix this stuff.
Is the game secretly a fiscal responsibility simulator with some armies thrown in for good measure? Yes, I guess it is, a little bit.

The naval game fits well into the ground game. The whole thing really feels like total war, with the razing of entire provinces. And it's the little things, like how the province erupts into flames, or the civilians in a besieged city run around in panic. It's the blood and guts and the way that the AI actually fields halfway decent fighting forces, or at the very least armies that look impressive while you roll them over.

It's not a Paradox game, but I can't hold that against a Total War entry. It's a Total War game, and a damn fine one at that. It's a shame that some reviewers with DLC axes to grind have relegated this to the dustbin of mixed" user reviews

reviewText:
Let me just start by saying that this is not your traditional Total War game. If you're looking to forge an unstoppable empire and assert cultural authority across the entirety of the campaign map, do not get this game.

In past TW titles, you are the architect of an empire the world will never forget. Attila does not ask for this. Instead, your aim is to survive until a certain date. This particularly applies to sedentary factions like West/East Rome. If you wish to play as anyone else, you will be given missions to loot and plunder regions, as opposed to conquer them. Of course, should you choose to conquer, there is an option for that. But unlike its predecessors, incorporating a recently conquered region doesn't reap the same benefits as it used to. In Attila, you're usually left with a city lacking in food and/or sanitation. You'll find yourself pouring more money into rebuilding its infrastructure and economy than creating armies. Whether you feel this is worth it is up to you, but personally, the incentive is lacking.

Now, here's the nit and grit.

PROS:

- Return of the family tree
- Refined political mechanics (you actually have to start caring about your generals and statesmen or they might mutiny)
- Beautiful graphics
- Concise UI, tech trees and building trees
- Ability to raze regions (helpful if you want extra dough, or to keep enemies from occupying as fertility is extremely downgraded)
- VIKINGS GOD DAMN IT!
- Archer units are actually useful now
- Noticeable AI improvements both in battle and on the campaign map (though, CA still has a lot of work to do in this department)
- Community still as great as ever!

CONS:

- Huns are OP, they literally spawn out of nowhere (how the hell is this fair CA!?)
- Lack of unit variations for barbarian armies. Actually no - just a lack of units in general.
- Essentially Rome II with mods and texture skins
- Why is everything on fire. We get it, Rome was dying, but Europe wasn't s*** on by Satan.
- DLC clusterf*** (blame SEGA, not CA)
- Battles are far too quick, so I would suggest a quick trip to the workshop as there are plenty of fixes. Play the campaign for a few hours, see what you want and don't want, then tailor to suit your desires.

I can definitely recommend this game to any TW or Strategy game enthusiasts, but if you spend enough time modding Rome II you'll have a better game there instead. I mean, are the Huns that different from Royal Scythia and Co?

Did you like Rome 2 Total War Emperor Edition? Buy this game, you won't regret it. Pros and Cons are already explained in other reviews. I write this review to explain the way AI cheats and the infamous DLCs.

First of all, AI did cheat in every Total War game, be it economically or in the battlefield. If you have played a campaign on Normal/Normal difficulites(which is the most equal one) - and of course assuming that you know how to play on campaing and battlefield - you can see that it is super easy and the game gets boring as hell. Take 5 settlements, have a good army that can not be defeated and that's it. You won, the other factions stand no chance and you face no challanges. This is because AI can not think as a human being and if we were to expect AI to think and play as a human being, we would dream in a really stupid way. So, to make the game more challenging, AI cheats in a way that does not always break the game.

And about the DLCs, I don't see a company that releases a game without DLCs. They all differ, but they just try to take your money with different additions to the main game that we all know they have planned or already prepared. So this is clearly the way the companies make their games. Unfortunately, complaining about this will not change anything. The game is not incomplete as many people say just because there are some faction DLCs. We have all the factions that feels different available already. What do you want to play as? Longbeards? Or the other Germanic factions around them? None of them feel much different than the Franks. Same religion, same roster excluding a few units, same starting location, same future enemies. Nordic fations? Same as Saxons. I would complain if they made WRE as a DLC faction, but the DLC factions are cleary not so much exciting. You don't feel like you missed something just because you didn't play as Longbeards. It is like complaining because in Rome Total War, Numidia is not available. Who cares? We have the Huns, WRE, ERE, Sassanids, Saxons, Franks and all of migrating factions. My point is that, you don't need the DLCs to enjoy the game and you don't miss anything just because you didn't buy them.

In conclusion, the game is really better than Rome2 TW EE and in my opinion, better than all the other Total War games and I played them since Medieval Total War. DLC factions worth nothing, you don't miss anything by not buying them. AI is improved in many ways but don't expect much. The game feels more challenging than any Total War game on Legendary and as long as you know how to play, cheating AI will not kill the game. But if you want to make it more equal, you can always make your difficulty Normal/Normal. Once again, if you like Rome 2 TW EE don't hesitate, you will like this game even more.

reviewText: I've been a fan of Total War since Rome 1 and I have to say I do not like the direction CA is taking the series. The fire system is great. The way that towns actually get feel like they get destroyed rather than just have a few buildings knocked down. The migratory factions are a great addition but all in all it feels like a $15 expansion to Rome 2 with a few additions and a new campaign. I still like the additions the game made and aside from the re-using assets it is a truly great game but I can't forgive CA all the DLC crap trying to get just a little more money. reviewText:
If there was an option inbetween recommended and not recommended i would have chosen it, its a good game but there are some issues with it and CA are doing some very shifty marketing.

Allow me to elaborate.

The Good
-You can abandon towns which makes the surrounding area desolate, allows for some nice scorch and burn tactics.
-Playing as the Western Roman Empire is SO much fun and difficult, being hated by basically everyone and outnumbered 5 to 1 at the beginning is a nice challenge but to make up for it your starting troops are far better then those pesky barbarians.
-Solid gameplay all round with majority of units being balanced in the sense that there is usually a counter to most of them.
-Looks very nice even on the lowest graphics settings.

The Bad
-AI blatantly cheat to make up for lack of intelligence e.g an army of 240 men becoming 1920 in 1 turn.
-Poor optimization; I know CA said the game was designed for the next series of GPUs but thats either a lame excuse for being lazy or they are just plain stupid, why would they design it for something we are not going to have for another 2 odd years?
-Locking out existing factions in the vanilla game and making you pay for them as DLC, excuse me CA but ♥♥♥♥ off they should be playable from the beginning. Hence shifty marketing.
-Diplomancy, AI refuse peace even when they are down to their last city unless they ask you and sometimes they will declare war for no reason even if they are far weaker then your faction.
-Imperium is horrible, you end up with -80 diplomancy penalties with other factions even if you only have 1 city.

I would avoid it until steam workshop becomes available and they make the DLC free.

Update 29/06/2015

The pay wall is still there for the factions that are 'DLC' when they are in fact apart of the vanilla game and you have to pay to see blood and gore, the AI has not improved and still cheats. CA is money grabbing in the extreme and i fear for the future titles, if they continue to force people to pay for things that should already be in the game or actually is then they will lose their audience and they will go to another franchise. CA you are not the only company out there and your horrendous marketing will not go unpunished.

reviewText:
I will update as time goes on with this one!

Alright, so a couple hours in and a bit of a gamble to get the game right off the bat.
Not sure what to say, but this is one heck of a step up from Rome 2. It looks the same, it sounds similar but it's a whole different world.

The campaign map is simply beautiful. I love the added detail and all the little changes!
The added touches to razing & besieging a settlement is much welcomed eye-candy.
Everything from birds to more detailed trees simply brought the campaign map to life!
I gotta love the increased camera zoom as well. Certainly doesn't make you feel boxed in anymore.

The actual battles are good, still getting the hang of the units and all the little nuances with them.
I can't say I adore the colour schemes though. Watching a bunch of Gothic spearman in battle kinda looks like a grey-green blob moving back and forth, until you zoom up close. I certainly miss the banners as well. I'm not too excited about these floating markers!

The UI is gorgeous on TW:Atilla. All the hype about easier to read trees, and skill progression is well met. It's so much easier to find things on the Campaign Map Screen. Everything is beautifully organized, CA really worked on getting everything streamlined and easier to access!

So far I've been happily playing the past few hours hitting 40-50 FPS on pretty much Max Quality. Not a lot of tweaking with the graphics so far, I just went along with the recommended!

I certainly look forward to getting more play time!

reviewText:
My opinion may be a little bias, being a long-time fan of the Total War franchise; but all things considered Total War Attila is a great game. It isn’t revolutionary; it doesn’t change the real-time or grand strategy genre as we know it. What it DOES do is provide a fun and engrossing continuation of the Total War series in an extremely interesting time period of mankind’s history. The core of the gameplay is still great fun, albeit a little repetitive at the later stages of campaign play. There are some nice, if small improvements to the latest instalment of the Total War series. Long-time Total War fans will enjoy the new factions, new horde and diplomacy mechanics and the new units of this fascinating historical period.

Some people criticise Creative Assembly for releasing Attila with day 1 faction DLC, and the limited number of factions playable for the base game. These critiques may have merit, but unfortunately the DLC model is well established and here to stay. Let us be thankful that Creative Assembly is releasing more mini-campaign DLC alongside the faction DLCs. Again, your experience might be different, but I have been pleasantly surprised at the lack of major bugs in the Attila release. It was very refreshing after the troublesome release of Rome 2. I almost didn’t pre-order Attila, but I am VERY glad I did. It has proven to be an amazing game. The one-more-turn-itis of Attila is strong, and has led to me racking up a cool 110 hours of the game since it was released only 3 weeks ago. Yes, the developers do need to tweak some aspects of the game but the core is solid and most important of all – FUN!!

I highly recommend this title to both Total War veteran and new-comers alike. Attila Total War fills a niche in the strategy market – it has elements of grand strategy - without the super detailed management of games like Civilization, Europa Universalis and the like; as well as the real-time strategy element sure to appease history buffs, aspiring tacticians and people who just want to see big groups of men charge into other big groups of men and hack them to pieces!

Check out the full detailed review with awesome pictures!! @ http://gamoha.eu/review-total-war-attila/

reviewText:
Been playing Total War since Rome 1 for reference.

This game is a return to form for the Total War franchise. After Rome 2 this game feels like everything that Rome should have been.

Visually the game has imorived by adding a fire mechanic and a siege escalation that brings some life to the cities and sieges. Watching building burn and fire spreading thru ought the city is deffinitely something to see, its that extra immersion you really appreciate.
On a game play side, the AI is performing much better than before, tho not perfect, the politics system has more depth to it that Rome 2, but still not to the level we wanted. The return of the family tree is much appreciated.
The food system has been drastically overhauled definitely adding a lot more strategy to province management, specialization of provences isn't easy like in Rome 2 and definitely equires a bit of planning.
Another small but useful change is making all the provinces have three regions.

In my campaign on Very Hard as Himyar I found it challening to expand into Egypt and squaring off against the Eastern Romans,  many battles had to be fought before I could get a single settlement and the AI moved its armies in strategic ways that actually withheld me frrom going forward, something that impressed me.
Public order isnt that easy to manage either, before I could go on my conquering rampage maintaining region control was important, while defending the same territory from the AI armies.
Playing in Europe is like racing against the clock in preperation for the Huns and if you can't stop em, then you better move, a sense of tension that is really engaging.

Agents are still very important but not as OP as in ROME 2, Spies definitely got nerfed and you won't see alot of poisining going on which I am ok with.

All in all the game requires more strategic thought than before wether you play as a nomadic tribe or not and that is something I appreciate.

There are still somethings that could have been done better and more features could have been added, diplomacy is still the same as before and I would really like the re-introduction of region trades but its probably not happening, AI is good but nor perfect but overall the positives far outweigh the negatives.

The game gets a solid 9/10 as both a Total War game and a strategy game.

reviewText:
The best of all Total Wars hands down !

Really, it's the same build as Rome, yet it feels so different, more refined, subtle...

There are great characters and political management here, great buildings and economy (with lot of though choices between raising more money, food, units, ressources, happiness, sanitation etc it's very intricate this time), the tech research is a bit straigthforward but with some tough choices anyway, the army management is so much better, the horde mechanism very well thought.
The general feeling of the end of the world is also noteworthy, both because of the scripted events regarding Attila and climate change as well as because the campaign feel chaotic and very fluid with all the razing of towns, the migrating hordes, the uprisings of new factions, the crumbling of the roman empire etc.

I also think that the siege escalation and destructions effects works well.

Historical purists will point some strange units in the rosters there and there (vikings etc), but given the overall lack of information about the time period i feel that most of those are good compromises to flesh out some factions and not too over the top like units in past CA titles...

An excellent title in the serie that set a high score to beat, i wouldn't have thought there would be so much change between Attila and Rome 2, yet they are totally different beasts.

Total War: Atilla. As you may have heard people complaining about the dlc's so early on in the game. But lets start with the good and the bad.

Pros:
- The game keeps you between a good mix of war and political matters and disputes meaning if you just ignore your political issues your faction will fall into despair. And if you don't have enough troops you will surely fall in battle

- The AI aren't pushovers they will destroy you completely if you do not pay attention to what you are doing.

Cons:

- Needs more bacon

- If you use mac it probably wont work


Review Continued :

After several hours I have found myself growing more strategic. Going from the simple I need to defend my land to I need to use guerilla warfare even though im a newb to it. The farther in game you get the farther you will realize peace is far from your door step and the only choice is to push forward.

At times you may feel outnumbered or completely beaten. But at those times you must fight. Fight for your peoples lives even if the numbers are against you and you will defeat your enemies and make them run.

With that said this game has changed my perspective on strategy and I really enjoy it. But if your buying it get it off a keys website. The dlc cost next to nothing on a key website and the game can be up to half price depending on your country.

reviewText:
CA is back baby! If you loved Shogun 2 and the past Total War games but felt let down by Rome II, you should go pick this game up ASAP. Rome II felt way to arcadey for me, the seiges sucked, They took out the family trree from Shogun2, the battles felt underwhelming, the ai stunk, the launch was not very good and it just wasn't alot of fun to play for me personally.

I was waiting to see some videos and hear the TW communities opinion on Attila and what I have seen and heard has been very positive so I had to buy the game a bit after release. The UI is improved and so much more that I will go into below.

The Family Tree from Shogun 2 is back and it is even better than ever with even more depth. The seiges and battles in general feel more satisfying and with more strategy involved. This here feels like the TW I have come to love over the years and makes me forget about Rome II and my distaste for it.

CA deserves alot of praise for listening to the community for this game, alot of the things that have been improved or added since Rome II was stuff I had seen the community talk about and stuff I had been dissapointed with. It is wonderful to see CA listen to the fans and make a much better game. I don't need anymore hours in this game to know that I enjoy it, we have our Total War back at full strength people!

There is a few issues such as the high requirements for the higher settings and some of the bugs, but overall it is a very good release, especially compared to Rome II on release. If you liked all of the TW games up until Rome II, pick this up ASAP. Even if you liked Rome II, pick this up, for me this is CA on the top of there game and it brings back memories from Shogun 2 and past TW games. Welcome back CA, this is a step in the right direction.

reviewText:
I usually dont review games but due to the discontent consumers have for this game and the last, Rome 2, I feel I should.
Objectively there are many good things about this game, using the order that they used for their store page Ill list what I feel.

Apocalyptic destruction mechanics, this part of the game is new to any total war that i have played, and i have played most excluding shogun 1 and 2. The only issue with this is that your army can get so terribly weak that a unit with 30 melee attack can be at much less than half of its strength at the BEGINING of a battle. Another issue is that if you are playing with battle limits and you are defending, a viable strategy might be to wait inside a walled settlement and see if the enemy come in range. This is useful when facing a much larger army but if that army does not want to come to you and the time limit nears completion, the smaller army will face a morale loss and may even route and run outside the walls to their deaths without your command. wonderful.

Legendary start position This is probably the hardest start position i have ever played across any total war game. It is incredibly hard since you are completely open to nomads and you may not even be able to field enough armies to fight them off.

Overhauled game mechanics You remember that cool civil war you fought in Rome 2? Mine only lasted about 3 turns but hey it was a suprise. See the issue here is that if you fight one civil war you will probably fight two or three more pretty damn soon. The loyalty system requires you to spend gravitas to keep people in line but since you lose gravitas you also lose control and thus suffer negative penalties. You spend gravitas to avoid penalties but spending gravitas gains penalties. yup. Would have been a cool thing if it wasnt done so oddly. I just adopt everyone so their is only one family and then hey whatever man. ill never look at that page again.

Incredible period detail  This is true for a little while but the issue is that this is history, remember when all of italy became a barren wasteland that is no where near fertile? the entire east became near uninhabitable when the rot grasped the land? No? well that incredible period detail only lasts a little while. No matter how long you play things will only get worse and never better so food is definitely a large worry.

Outstanding visual fidelity they did truly do something lovely here. They made a graphics setting that is meant for the future. You guessed it, instead of fleshing out the game for the present they made settings for the future. So in 3 years when your computer is good enough to play on the best settings you will have no new content left to play unless you are willing to buy 15 dollars worth of content that could have been in the game. One of my favorite childhood games was dynasty warriors, i remember vividly having to actually beat the game to unlock content. Now its so much better that i get to buy stuff i already payed for to play the game i bought.

All in all if you like old total war games you may like this one, You really are going to get upset at CA though. If you are new to total war maybe you wanna look at an older one. It wont be as pretty but you will have more to do.

Having eagerly anticipated the most recent installment of this franchise I cannot say I can recommend it for the price it is.

The campaign itself is challenging which is a nice change from most other Total War games. However, the UI (in my honest opinion) lets it down, it is clunky and is a step down from the sleekness of Total War: Rome 2. As well as this the much lauded 'graphic changes' don't appear to have materialised at all.

Gameplay is fine, as to be expected with any CA game, but nothing special nor an improvment on the Rome 2 offering.
Essentially it is Rome 2 with a new skin and is simply not worth the price, even on this current 33% off sale. Wait for it to come down in price, it certainly isn't worth £29.99 at full price, or the current £20.99 in this flash sale.

I am glad it became free for this weekend in order for me to gather opinions on this game, sadly I won't be buying it at anything more than around the £15 mark.

Essentially Rome 2 with a much more clunky UI and doesn't run as smooth. Overall, an underwhelming DLC.
