reviewText:
It’s a cruel irony when the expansion is better than the original game. But that is exactly what has happened. The launch of Rome 2 was a disaster from which Creative Assembly are still recovering and in Total war Attila they have attempted to distance themselves from the confusing mess of the previous game and create a much more refined, challenging and enjoyable one.

Before Total war Attila, there were two Total war games focused around an historical figure; Alexander and Napoleon. Alexander was clearly marketed as an expansion and it succeeded, because it captured the dynamic, fast paced campaign of the great monarch so well. Napoleon was an expansion in all but name and failed; because it tried to turn itself into a fully fledged standalone game and at the same time maintain a direct focus on Napoleon.

Total War Attila is in-between the two in almost every way. It perfectly captures the intense desperation of the collapse of the Roman Empire, but the large number of playable factions and the detail in the campaign map gives it much more depth than Napoleon ever had. Attila is playable, but he is not the main focus of the game; he is a driving terror working behind the scenes. This allows the focus to shift depending on who you are playing as. For some migrating tribes you flee from the Huns, others flee from a hostile climate, others batter their way through the decaying wreck of Rome. The game is harder, and there are more adversaries that encourage you to keep playing until the late game.

First of all the campaign map. It is a marked improvement from Rome 2, with family trees, improved stances, terrain and city management. The family tree system is not as easy to understand as the original Rome, but it does make your generals more important, and that is important. But the other features of the campaign map mean success of the game does not depend on characters alone; similar to Empire, there are wider issues afoot. The climate works against you and can force you to change your strategy entirely. This leads into migrations, which add a whole new way of playing Total war. Yes, it is like barbarian invasion, but far better.

But the focus of a good Total war game shouldn’t be on the campaign alone. Don’t get me wrong, it is very important that the map doesn’t become bland and repetitive like Rome2, but I think of it this way: the first total war game I bought was the original Rome, not because I wanted to manage taxes and buildings for the ancient world, but because I saw Time Commanders on BBC 2 and thought to myself ‘I want a piece of that action!’, and battles in Total war Attila are honestly disappointing. True, unit cohesion and unit collision don’t suffer from any serious flaws and the Ai is smarter. However, battles are a case of two steps forward one step back, as units tire much faster and rout far too easily; after around a minute of combat. Battles that look terrifying on the campaign map turn out to be a walk over on the battle map. This is disappointing.

Finally we get to the elephant in the room. Is Total war Attila an expansion or a proper standalone game? This is the question that seems to determine whether so many people decide whether or not to buy it. I think this is because people are put off by the perceived link to the disaster of Rome 2, but look at it this way; if someone was trying to get into Total war and you had to recommend to them either Rome 2 or Attila – which would it be?

Attila is not perfect but it is a step in the right direction for CA, showing that they can still make a good game. Contrary to many others I defend the DLC choices made for Attila - the faction packs are not vital for the full game experience like the Greek City Sates were, but what did annoy me rather was the release of Longbeards days after the game first went live. But anyway, Total war Attila is a marked improvement over Rome 2 and I would definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
So yes, this game is 'essentially' the same as Total War Rome 2, but it is also much better and more in depth. The main changes to the game are many, but they are mainly centered around the UI (user interface) on the campaign map.

The foremost thing most people will probably notice is that all the building icons have been changed (they look really cool now I think) and you have been given a TON more information about said building and a variety of stuff pertaining to the city or proviince you have selected. Specialized buildings are also available now if a city has a resource available to it, which is really cool becasue some of these resources can actually have a really big impact on your or the AI's economy and it can be devastating if you or even the AI loses one of the places. Sanitation and sqaulor have actually been given a purpose now outside of just making people happy/unhappy by balancing each other with the chance of a disease outbreak if squalor is higher than sanitation. Diseases work fairly in a really interesting way, they can spread across cities and through trade routes or an army can infect an entire other province if its sanitation is outweighed by squalor. The biggest impact of a disease is bascially just a public order penalty, building a sanitation structure in the province can easily remedie its impacts.

Apart from the new unit icons and units being faster to fatigue and breaking, not much has changed with the RTS side of Total War Attila. I liked the old unit banners I think, but once you get used to it they can be useful at figuring out what a unit is with just a glance, and holding spacebar gives you information on every unit's moral and fatigue, which is much preferbale I think to hovering your cursor over each individual unit. There is also a new icon that appears at the bottom left of an enemies unit icon when you have one of your units selected that indicates how great a threat that enemy unit is, another nice yet small change. Fatigue is a much greater hinderance than it was in any previous total war game, as it barely takes any time for a unit to become exhausted and lose moral/fighting effectiveness as a result. Thankfully I think this is faily well balanced with shorter time to recuperate stamina and more elite units' resistance to those penalties. Units can break faster, but they can also come back faster. Unfortunately I am not sure what I think of this as thus far when teh unit breaks from combat they suffer additional casualties from getting attacked in the rear. So when they stop routing they are basically useless because they suffer additional moral penalties from too many losses and if you don't have a general nearby they can route and come back almost a dozen times (true story).

Last but not least, I think I'll just touch on  a few small complaints I have and try to explain why I like this game more than Rome 2.

During the RTS battles, the one thing that a absolutely hate with all my being is the inability to take down the 'pinned unit' tab that can take up almost an eighth of your screen during a battle. I do find it really useful for comparing unit stats, for both my units and the enemies, but it is really ridiculous that it is basically the only tab you can't minimize and it constantly has to take up so much of your screen. It also took me a while to figure out that this same tab can be further expanded and you can see more detailed unit stats, something I should have known fro the moment I started recruiting units, but there was no advance waring (though keep in mind I turn off advisor and didn't play through the tutorial/prologue).

That is about my only major complaint apart from the faction politics system, I still find the system redundant (apart from now that you have to worry about heirs) becasue there are just too few events relative to it and nothing really has an impact on power balance unless you blow ridiculous amounts of money on really stupid endeavours. I will add though that apart from the expense apointing people to administrative positions, the bonuses you get from putting an individual into a certain 'office' is a nice added feature.

What makes this game so much better now though, I think, is the new nomadic system and the shear importance of even a single army and how key one can be to a faction's survival. Playing as either of the Roman factions, the last thing you are worried about (apart from maybe the byzantines) is territorial conquest. You will likely be so focused on trying to keep your armies alive and consolidating your borders that there is really no time to think about conquest. Having so many factions going rampant across your borders alos impacts your income, there is nothing in the game that actually explains it (again, I have advisor turned off and did not play the prologue), but simply having any enemy army present in your territory can cause your income to drop significantly. Thus far I think it mostly has to do with trade, though there is no indication that trade is being affected or anything, you just have a reduced income. Though as much as it s a major challenge having so many full stacks against you, for the naomadic factions these armies are also an achilles heel. Most of the nomadic factions never exceed two full armies, but since they are also mobile settlements you can drastically impact such a faction's power by destroying one of these stacks. So focusing down the stacks of a nomadic faction and killing as many of them in battle as possible can be hugely rewarding. Playing as the Romans though, this is not so easy because you have very few cavalry units to start (which are invaluable in running down enemies when they are routed so you can wipe their stack) and most nomadic factions have a lot of cavalry. Early on I think this is fairly well balacned because the lack of the Romans' cavalry units can deny them running down all the enemy forces, allowing them to fight another day. This is what I really enjoy about Attila thus far becasue it makes each army in the game much more important and definetly adds a new level of survival to the game.

Sorry for such a long bout, but that is the gist of what I value from this game in the first week of its release.

reviewText:
The period directly after the fall of the Western Roman Empire and before the Renaissance is often referred to as the Dark Ages. One of the leading figures in bringing about the Dark Ages in which many great achievements were lost, forgotten and not to be repeated for nearly a millenia, was Attila. A man who saw a rich, once mighty empire in peril and saw an opportunity to rip some people off before the rotten edifice finally collapsed.

It could be argued that Rome was already on an inexorable downward spiral and Attila mearly helped hasten the inevitable, but one thing cannot be argued. After Attila had finally finished his ruining of Rome, the francise could never recover and the Dark Ages were beckoning.

Maybe a more generous attitude and greater Mod Support could have helped save Rome, rather than nickle and diming its plebs for blood pack dlc. Who knows, but maybe in a thousand years time we may see another game pick up where the original Rome Total War left off.

This game is ♥♥♥♥ btw, if my review wasn't clear.

reviewText:
I have had Total War: Attila since launch, and have purchased every DLC with the exception of the Last Roman Campaign ($15 is a little pricey for me.) Having said those three letters, DLC, I know that will instantly turn off a number of people from buying this game and they will stop reading this review right here.

Now, for those of you who are still reading, you're in for a treat. TW:A is the most fun I've had in a Total War since shooting my first flaming catapult shot in Medieval 2. For those of you who haven't played, that's pretty damn fun. But back to Attila, which is an absolutely great game, whether you like Grand Campaign, multiplayer, or just dicking around in custom battles. Everything from the fire dynamics to the VASTLY improved naval battles highlight the fact that Creative Assembly has really listened to the complaints of RTW2. I know what you're thinking though, Listened?? le DLC tho!!1!!!"

Yes. This game has a number of DLCs
date: no way around it. But they aren't your average
hoursPlayed:
but rather unique and fun little additions that add a better overall experience. Plus three new factions! For example, the cool bonuses the Desert factions get in the Empire of Sands DLC create a totally new way to play the game. Or the Viking Forefathers pack which gives you all sorts of cool little questlines that pop up, with the consequences of your decisions creating a unique general to recruit for Grand Campaign.

Is it perfect? No. Do I recommend you buy all the DLC? No. I really love this historical time period and so I had no problem paying a little more, but I realize that isn't the case for everyone. What I do recommend though is picking up TW:A next time it's on sale, and giving it a go. I promise you will have a good time, DLC or no DLC. I don't understand how this game has a 67% positive rating (at time of review) other than people hating because of DLC, which is understandable to a point. CA really did a good job on this one, overabundant DLC be damned, that shouldn't overshadow that this is a seriously fun game.

8.5/10

reviewText:
What I liked:
+The battles are very well done and feel very exciting
+Units have been balanced quite well compared to its predecessor, Rome II
+The campaign mode is very, very fun to play and change history with. For example, after the Western Roman Empire fell in my Geats campaign, I settled all of Italy and started a Geatish Empire based out of Scandanavia.
+Diplomacy and politics are back in this game, after they were stripped from Rome 2. There are actual meaningful effects that occur from random events, like the death of the Pope. If you're a Christian faction, which I was during my WRE playthrough, you'll get a huge public order penalty across your nation and you must find a way to overcome it. You also need to make sure your ruler/ruling party is maintaining a respectable level of control as well as allowing others a position of power, or else you'll have a civil war... and you don't want a civil war.
+The graphics are quite impressive but nothing ground-breaking, even with Extreme settings on. Nonetheless, it'll make your game look pretty enough.
+Very stable right now. I haven't encountered any bugs or glitches for a long time, except for one: when your men are in Defensive Testudo (a heavy defensive formation) and they are in heavy combat for a while, sometimes they will reform their formation sideways or something, allowing the enemy to hit them from behind. You just need to keep an eye on them and make sure their formation is facing the correct way.
+The UI is great. It feels modern, and I always have a difficult time going back to the old Total War games because I am spoiled from CA's advancements in their recent titles.
+The campaign AI is much better this time around. They'll actually bring large armies to oppose you, and in logical ways. The Romans make decisions as they did in the real life timeline, the Huns are very tough to deal with no matter which faction you play as, and the Sassanids use their vassals to create huge problems for you.
+The time period itself is interesting, good choice by CA.

Some things I didn't like:
-The DLC whoring, though CA themselves probably doesn't have much control over it. Honestly, this doesn't bother me much because the unique factions come in the base game. Those DLC packs are just 3 copy-and-paste factions sold for $8. Long story short, you won't be missing anything if you skip the DLC - just as it should be.
-The classic Total War battle AI is back. They made steps forward with Attila, but there are some returning issues. If the AI doesn't know where you are" (they always know)

reviewText:
Total War: Attila is the latest iteration on the series with turn-based strategy and real-time tactical combat set in the time period during the fall of the Roman empire.

What is Great about this game:

- Mechanically, the most sophisticated and playable Total War game to date
- Family trees and factional politics are implemented smartly and with real consequences
- Improved faction options such as creating hordes and relocating improve strategic depth

What is Good about this game:

- Good use of Steam features such as cloud saves, trading cards, etc

What is Bad about this game:

- The game is centered around the fall of the Roman empire and as such is set in a relatively bleak period
- The difficulty of the game seems tuned for players that want a constant struggle (perhaps related to the setting as well)
- Due to its setting, the campaign of the Romans is centered largely around maintenance and defense" of the existing empire rather than on the generally more enjoyable "expansion through conquest" of Total War: Rome 2

Conclusion:

Take Total War: Rome 2 and put in significantly better strategy mechanics but place it in a less appealing
recommended: and more difficult setting and you have an excellent Total War game if perhaps not quite pinnacle of the series.\n\n9.0 / 10.0"

reviewText:
Preface: I've only put in 32ish hours so far, I've played as ERE/WRE/Huns/Sassanids all past 400AD and played a handful of multiplayer battles. Total War: Attila is quite likely the best game in the total war franchise. Maybe not the best for its time but by a close margin I'd put it just ahead of M2.

Gameplay:Amazingly diverse campaign playstyles (empire in decline, migrators, conventional start and safe empires)
Battle mechanics are improved (fatigue and morale are more intersting, units return to the fight more and you have to give more thought to fatigue (tired quickly but you also recover faster, makes running more tactical).
Balance so far feels very good, nothing is insanely OP (that I've discoverd yet)
Unit diversity is huge, there are a wide range of factions and faction styles which makes the game intersting and I predict will increase replayability.
Battle AI (including siege) is substantially improved from previous games, it now makes logical decisions (I've found they're a tiny repetitve however.
Family tree is highly immersive and complicated which gives greater depth to the game (especially in the long run)
The economic system is a fair bit more complicated than R2 and is more interesting as it changes over time (climate change) and involves an increased number of relevant variables (immigration, religion, desolation/raiding etc.)
Diplomacy feels similar to R2 but slightly more polished, the ability to gift factions to migrator factions is a nice addition. Overall small improvement here.
Siege escallation is great fun and adds more complexity. Gladly the AI also makes good use of this most of the time (at province capitals)
Graphics/Performance Played on a GTX970, i53570k on a 4k monitor.
Textures etc. are a small step up from R2, they aren't amazing up close though.
Good detail in units
Game performs above 30FPS at 4k on 'performance' (with some max performance mixed in), drops to high twenties when I zoom in with a large number of units.
Overall performance is okay but could improve, the forward looking approach of the 'extreme' graphics settings is comendable to help ensure their game lasts.
Meta Stuff Day 1 DLC is annoying but common in the industry, neither a negative or a positive
The fact that they've made the improvements that the community have made (on the whole) is highly commendable. They appear to have learnt from their errors.
If you liked R2 you'll love this, if you didn't like R2 you may find some enjoyment in this game but it won't amaze you.
I haven't encountered any game breakings bugs, the new path drawing system however is a little bit unreliable though.

I agree it's bullsh*t but the game itself is too good to pass up because of the DLC BS.

Now to the game itself. I immediately noticed the improvements when I started my campaign as the Saxons. First of all I love all of the new options and family mechanics. I'm not very good at describing things, but for whatever reason the entire game seems to feel very smooth as compared to Rome 2 which was very rigid. (Although a great game I do recommend Rome 2 to everyone)

The only thing I can even remotely complain about is the DLC rip off, which while indeed is a ripoff, is not enough to keep me from enjoying this marvelous addition to the Total War franchise.

Thank you for reading, feel free to add me at anytime if you would like to play a battle.

reviewText: Total War Attila is great, with major changes from Rome II. I'm so disappointed in the game it has inspired me to write my first review. I have played every Total War game since I got Rome Total War in 2005. And this game is so sad…
Overall it's better than Rome 2. (Others have explained this really well already) But that's if you can get the game up and running. I have twice the RAM, 3 TB hard drive, and a far more powerful graphics card than the recommended requirements and I can't get a decent frame rate even on the lowest settings. And that's only assuming it won't crash.
Technical issues aside let's reflect momentarily on how this is basically an updated and prettier version of the Barbarian expansion pack for the original Rome. The main difference being that the Barbarian expansion pack wasn't masquerading around as a full game worth $44.99 and when you bought it you bought all of it. What they’ve done here is make an expansion pack for Rome 2, sold it as a full priced game, and then hacked it up with culture packs and campaigns worth as much as the original Rome’s expansion packs each.
So in conclusion; they are ripping us off with something that barely works anyways. And I’m very sad to see my absolute favorite franchise go down the tubes. RIP Total War I will always miss the hundreds of hours of procrastination we had together.

reviewText:
900+ hours of my life lost… My fault but here’s why:

It's easy to pick holes or criticise something, as human beings it’s in our nature. We always will have a portion of our brain that tells us that ‘something’ could be done better… And it’s with the awkward wisdom of hindsight I begin my two pennies of thought on this latest ‘Total War’ release. For those who have never played a Total War game before, I do apologise in advance for not being concise enough for a balanced review or completely detailed report.

I’ve always been an avid fan of the growing database that controls CA’s Total War series that was first launched with the original ‘Shogun – Total War’. Although I have to admit, from a solo player point of view the ‘Zerg’ style AI scripting that ensues throughout, seems to ruin things for an overall strategy game. By this I mean, it’s ‘no’ matter how you start, the end is the same when it comes to the final push. This is hugely lame and in my individual opinion, is a shining example of how bad some game designers are in employment or more so, over-paid Producers (For the record, I worked at various gaming publishers and can name quite a few that ‘should’ have never have been employed in such a role – utterly clueless to gaming – “Apologies for the rant, but it is relevant”).

For my part, the only way to scale a strategy game in difficulty is to simply incur penalties to the roll of a die or likewise incur penalties for ‘bad’ decisions – a simple mathematical notion but for a game, it is a rewarding dynamic of randomness. But after 900 hours+ on Attila, 700 hours+ (Total War – Rome 2) and an insane (according to Steam) – and I really hate to publish this fact. Although I think many hours were because the PC was left on overnight *coughs* – 3800+ hours on Total War – Shogun 2. I have to come to an eventual and final conclusion, “Complete waste of time”.

The combat on field is great fun; UI is good, graphics, sound and so on. All detailed, rewarding and completely atmospheric. Hard to fault and mainly because it’s almost as good as it gets on that front. The complete and utter jewel in the crown of the entire series and lead to many a late night of “Just one more…”. And to be honest, I don’t think even the hardiest gamer could be bored with the thrill of detailed RTS (Real Time Strategy) battles.

But you’re left feeling divorced from your 20 minute+ achievements when taken back to the ‘real’ part of the game – i.e. the ‘Campaign Map’. Rather than feel like a conqueror, you’re simply adding to your invisible foe’s strengths – even when using agents and so on. When you push, they push back and more – no matter what your style or tactics in play. In the end, your achievements in Attila (and the recent Total War games) are very counterproductive.

So if you don’t care about gaming and just want a laugh – buy it. Play it and I dare say in 2-Player mode it’s probably the best in a turn based with RTS/Strategy you could find. But for a solo player, I would rather be sat in a prison cell with a deck of cards, with each card being the same colour/suit.

PS: Funny how most ‘professional’ game reviewers come up with the same scores… Having worked alongside many publishers in the UK during the 90’s, I’ve always wondered how they can tell the difference between their mouths and arses. Both portals seem to produce the same excrement when priced in wealth and insight.

PPS: Warhammer in CA’s hands – yeaaaah riiiight… Nice GFX I bet, but RPG/Roll of a die gameplay? You may as well handle dog poo and make a sandwich without washing your hands, and see if the randomness of picking up something ‘horrible’ is more prevalent than the £40+ bundle that is edging it’s way to the Steam Store soon…

It's sad seeing a game this good being bombarded by negative reviews just because of the DLC. As a game, Attila is perhaps the best Total War title to date, surpassing even the fan favourites Shogun 2 and Medieval 2. Attila has so many great features which the earlier total wars don't have. Every time I go back to rome 2 or shogun 2 I wish it had the city burning, migration, politics, the UI etc. of Attila. It's very hard for me to get back to those earlier titles (especially rome2) again after playing Attila.

Attila, when compared to Rome2, is superior in almost every way, except performance. Everything from battle to politics to campaign gameplay feels and is more fleshed out. Both the campaign and battle AI are phenomenal in the Total War standard. It's not great, but it is simply the best when compared to other total war titles.

Total War: Attila has an amazing atmosphere. The crumbling empires, cold, long winters, starvation, overall misery and the inevitable hunnic horde of thousands and thousands of warriors with the objective of raiding/killing/♥♥♥♥♥♥/burning your lands and cities. These presented with a gritty/grim colouring and graphics, make this total war title my absolute favourite. And I've played ALL Total War games.

The idea of having a final boss" in a total war game is brilliant. There is absolutely nothing more satisfying in any total war game

reviewText:
Definitely the Napoleon of Rome II. Some say it is a copy and paste of Rome II, but I disagree, even by the end of all the patching that game was a disaster without mods. Attila is better in every way essentially, better tech tree, better town management and building, better combat options (because apparently half the troops in Rome II couldn't use loose spacing), the barbarians are represented better, the AI actually build armies now and aren't horrifically braindead with their building choices (yes AI, build 16 farms across one region...), more depth in siege battles, agents are less overpowered (you can't get a champion almost instantly anymore), the ground is FAR more detailed and well themed, ranged units have more depth and are more balanced, family tree/government is usable and has a point again and better skill progression of characters.

There's a few things I don't like however, namely; general's bodyguard units are too weak later on in the game, but more importantly, you no longer get a choice of bodyguard units, which is my most hated change for some reason, I liked in Rome that you got a choice from like 3-5 different units, often a really fun unit like elephants or chariots.

The raze settlement mechanic is far too imbalanced. It is way too easy for the player and the AI to raze a settlement, often able to attack, sack and raze in one turn. Razing does far too much permanent damage to the player or AI and it is too costly and time consuming to settle on a razed location. Due to this and the AIs fondness with razing, the campaign map ends up mostly razed and deserted.

Online Co-op Campaign matches dysync FREQUENTLY. Often you can attempt a resync, which takes ages, while other times the game just closes.

No workshop........... really?

The AI are still far too diplomatically stubborn and stupid, they very rarely accept reasonable deals, almost never accept peace even if they are very far away and weak unless you pay a hellish amount of money. I have had a situation where I paid them a considerable amount for a non agression pact, only for them to break it the FOLLOWING turn and also declining my trade offer, only for them to ask to trade a few turns later. I've also had the AI break three treaties including non agression by declaring war in a single turn but suffer no diplomatic penalty to other factions.

The horde system is really cool, but due to the AI diplomacy I mentioned above it is pointless to stay as a horde for any extended period of time. As a horde you cannot seem to request military access (not that the AI would agree anyway), probably because as a horde you own no land for them to access in return, but an option to get access for money would be helpful. Anyway, due to that, factions get angry at you for trespassing even if you have a defensive alliance and they will eventually declare war on you, bribe more people into the war against you, never take peace due to their stubborness, repeat until the whole world hates you and tracks you down and you lose. You shouldn't have to pay above 20k to get a weak faction to stop fighting you at the start of the game. Not only that but making puppet states doesn't seem to work because of how much your state will hate you and then declare war on you later anyway.

The game doesn't run as well as Rome II, which I expected considering how much better it looks, but i'm sure improvement could be made here. The game sometimes will freeze up between turns, it doesn't happen often and thankfully it does not crash the game, but it is still annoying. This seems less prevelant now than at launch though.

Unit portraits don't look as good as Rome II, they had a really cool theme going and I think they could have made it work again by making the painting look a bit darker. Also, the voice actor for all of the non Roman/Eastern factions is the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ one from Rome II.

First two culture packs were clearly cut from the original game to be sold/used as a preorder bonus. Frustrating, but was bound to happen due to almost all big publishers being jews now days. If you thumbs down the game or not buy it because of this then I really can't blame you on that principle. Hopefully we get free stuff like we did in Rome II, but I doubt it because Attila wasn't a disgrace on launch so there's no need for damage control. In saying that, I do feel that the price of Attila was pretty great.

I'd like to see a heap more unit types and some more playable factions though, I'm willing to pay for that if it is good value, most importantly however, MORE GENERAL UNITS.

Overall a hell of a lot better than Rome II though, aint no Shogun 2, but it earns the Total War name. The Steam reviews are incredibly harsh on Attila, like seriously, the % of recommends is lower than Rome II, which I cannot fathom.

8/10

reviewText:
I came.  I saw.  I s**t my pants...    8/10.

This game is markedly better than the unfinished steaming pile of horse droppings that was Rome 2.  Basically, it is what Rome 2 should have been.  However, units are still way too similar and can still do very stupid things.  There is also very few factions to choose from and most of them feel like generic clones of each other..  The ERE is also pretty much identical to the WRE but for a few different buildings and starting situation (as best I can tell).

Overall though this game is a lot of fun.... would have been nice to be able to start Rome as a small faction, however if you want to play as Rome you start off with a MASSIVE empire and just get smashed constantly by barbarians (can wear thin after a while).  Still waiting on blood and gore..!!

After Shogun 2, CA seemed to have abolished the option to choose short, medium or long campaigns... I seem to never actually finish a campaign because they are simply faaaaaar too long and I get bored and want to start afresh (it can also become too easy when you are cleaning everybody up with ease)

Upgrade system and family tree are a HUGE improvement from Rome 2, although politics are still not explained very well..

This game is a lot of fun and in my opinion easily worth $50 (although CA will probably charge at least this much again by selling us missing chunks of the game in pieces).  Would love to see a medieval version!    There is still a slight moshpitting cowardice illness - the units behaving like idiots who seem to prefer to hide en mass in a long column rather than make a line and spread out and fight properly, but the mechanics as well as the AI are vastly improved from ROME 2.  What was amazing about the first Rome was the feeling of mass... when units hit each other you felt it!  This was almost non-existant in Rome 2 but is certainly improved in it's successor.. although, sadly, it is still inferior to what Rome 1 gave us so many years ago..... sigh..

Overall:  8/10 (I would give Rome 2 a 4/10 although made better by modders - there is as of yet no workshop for Attila which is a shame given that ROME 2 was basically unplayable without mods).

reviewText:
Attila Total War is a great game. The AI, even on normal difficulty, is challenging. I've liked most of the Total War games, but this is among the better ones. Each faction is engaging, especially with the new migration options and horde mechanics, it allows the player the option to make their own history nearly from scratch, whether one creates an Ostrogothic Persia or a Vandal Britannia or an Alani Scandinavia.

On release, this game was and is leaps and bounds ahead of Rome 2 Total War as a comparison. Although, the game still has tweaks and fixes that are necessary, I am sure they will be fixed given time. There are some historical inaccuracies that will annoy history nerds, like myself,  but they aren't game-breaking. One example being the Alani tribe: in game their roster is almost entirely German as is their appearance, yet they are an Iranian Sarmatian tribe - closely related to the Roxolani and Iazyges tribes. Their appearance and roster should be more like that of the Rome 2 Nomads than what it is now. The Huns, at the moment, have more powerful infantry than they do cavalry - which is baffling. There aren't any Slavic, Celtic, Semitic, or African tribes (yet) but it's still possible they may release in the future with DLC.

Campaign Gameplay: 8/10
Battle Gameplay: 7/10 (Still very quick battles)
Mechanics: 7/10 (Needs polishing, may change)
Replayability: 9/10
Graphics: 10/10 (The Raze function is amazing)
History: 5/10

Average: 7.7/10

reviewText:
From the very beginning this is probably the most challenging of all the the Total Wars, But definetly the most FUN and epic!

Playing as the Danes, I had lost my one and only territory by the 2nd turn (this sort thing happens a lot! Especially in the early game)! My King was dead and my army crushed after it had succesfully defended one enormous invaision by the Jutes, just to have the remnants be slaughtered by Varinians that then desolating my home. But all was not lost. For my heir-apparant was away doing what Vikings do best, piliging! And so my fleet was spared the barbarian onslaught and now the Jutes had no army nor navy to defend their city. So, the following turn I regrouped, reinforced my navy and turned their bows to face the Jute menace. In the space of two turns I had destroyed what was left of the Jutes forces, conqured their capital and taken all they had and restablishing my kingdom.

Basically, in Attila (unlike previous TW incarnations) losing all your settlements does not mean 'GAME OVER!'. Thanks to the great new migration system and the return of the family tree, which completes and improves the old politics sytem of Rome II, the 'end' doesn't necisarily mean the end. Overal this is a great improvement over Rome II and you wont be disappointed.

reviewText:
As a Total War game the formula is familiar, but also has its share of differences. One of the most notable is one of the best AI's I have ever seen in a stratagy game. Allies aid you, even if they are far away over the course of a long seige, as would a human ally. Enemies are cunning and use the gameplay against the player on the campaign map. Splitting your armies via subterfuge and cold/calculating manouvers.

It is also very visually appealing, though it has its rough edges in the performance sector as does every total war game at the start, but it is many times over better than Rome 2 in this regard. Stable and fairly bugless. Even the Co-op is very stable. It is obvious they have learned their lesson from Rome 2.

There are some things that are a bit wonky though, its color scheme on the campaign map while fitting for the mood, can make seeing things on the campaign map a bit of a challenge unless you adjust your brightness/Gamm settings. And battles are more often taking place in rain, snow, and fog than in clear weather.

The politics system is also greatly improved, and the addition of the family tree along with its gameplay is very welcome. Its a complicated TW, so dont expect to instantly pick up everything. One of the best TW games to date, I give it a 9/10.

reviewText: While this version of total war is considerably better than Rome 2, it's still pretty weak. Once again we are capped at 14 armies. Once again we can only build 6 buildings in the settlement. The only difficulty you will have is C/A making the game harder with things like infant mortality, the plague and so on. I tried playing as the Lombards, every single one of my male heirs died? I thought i did something wrong, so i started over. Again, every one of my male heirs dies, someone gets made king that isn't even in the family tree, and i can control nothing. Silly. Or you have a flood that destroys a city every 5 turns, or it will be a fire. Something always very unrealistic that just throws a wrench in to what you are doing, making you waste resources and time. I don't think Winchester burned to the ground every other year, did it? And honestly, i want the enemy to make the game hard, not the damn plague, or the inability to make a food building. I don't know what the reasoning is for making the game so much smaller and more mean spirited, but i mean come on, killing every male child is kind of morbid, don't you think? Anyway, i haven't played total war since Empire and Medievil 2, and i was totally stunned to see how much it has shrunk, it's depressing. C/A had totally sold out, nothing cutting edge here anymore. Just a stripped down version of the old games, with some new mechanics and graphics thrown in. Let's all get even with them by not buying this game anymore, maybe it will be a wake up call for them.

After 1700hrs+ playtime. reviewText:
Definetly a huge improvement on rome 2. Both the campaign map and the battle map color scemes are far better, making the terrain more realistic and crisp looking. The AI is also definetly improved, as when I was in battle, the huns act different and attack different than the Goths, and so on for all the factions. Also, viking factions seem to go more for a naval army, and inland germanic factions go for a lot of land, so the campaign AI is balanced to adapt to it's surroundings, where ever that may be. I also must say the music is a good improvment, as rome 2's music seemed boring at times, Attila's music is definetly adding to the overall immersion of the game.

I have, however found some early bugs and overlooked details, such as in some battles (mainly siege battles) the AI units get caught on an invisible barrier, or they all want to go stand on exactly the same spot, creating circular groups of bodies that won't stop running towards the center of the blob, until attacked. On one occasion, even, my units got caught on an invisible barrier, and attempted to go around it by trying to walk into the sea? Another topic I would like to bring to attention is in siege battles, if you attack by land and the AI has a mix of land and naval units, it can choose to not disembark its artillery or archers, so in minor settlements even if you wipe out the entire enemy force, you can't win the battle because of a few boats just sitting off shore, out of ammo and useless. These are all minor bugs, and I know they will be fixed, probably within the first patch, so I don't let them feel too immersion breaking.

I could go on and on about how many improvments there are, but in my opinion the ones listed are the major ones. overall this game gets a 9/10.

reviewText:
Like many others, I am a long term fan of the Total War series, having played since the first MTW. This game is certainly an improvement on RTW2, but in reality, it is nothing more than a reskin of that game and the changes that have been implemented should have also been included in RTW2. That they haven't speaks volumes about the mindset of the devs.

Despite this, game play is nothing to write home about and I didn’t find myself excited by this game during any stage. Unlike other incarnations of the series prior to RTW2, I never felt engaged by my empire building. Indeed a continual sense of frustration was about the only coherent thread running through my time with this game.

The issues that ruined play are still there. I won’t go into boring detail, as many of the other players have already pointed them out. Limits on Armies that don’t seem to apply to the AI and which turn the task of resupplying armies into a micromanagement nightmare. A province system that forces you to overextend if you want to fully develop your lands and which just feels arbitrary and clunky.

The encyclopaedia function was bugged and on several occasions required a restart to get working and then had a “yet to be translated” message plastered all over entries, despite the fact that I am plying in English.

Unit rosters are dull, limited and without variety as shared by fairly much everyone. Much yawnage to be had.

And perhaps worse, is that the game has shipped with only a fraction of the actual game content activated and we are expected to buy the rest of it in instalments that will most likely end up more than doubling the cost of the game.

Reality is that the previous incarnations of the series are far better investments for your time, energy and money and have the benefit of having a complete game at purchase.

I don't recommend this game to any but the most die hard, or carelessly rich.

reviewText:
Total War: Attila is by no means the best Total War game. But oh boy, does it come close. I have thoroughly enjoyed this game, and I never expected this time period to be so entertaining or enthralling. I found myself researching actual historic battles during this time, the rise of the Huns, and the fall of the Roman Empire. Why? I don't know! It's just so good!


Why you should buy this game-
-Half the expected price at release- you get a full game for $50.
-In around 70 hours of playing, I have seen next to no bugs. Compared to Rome II, this game is polished beyond description.
-The game is beautiful, and even though at times it doesn't seem to be completely optimised, I found myself in awe watching huge battles unfold, watching fires and explosions and water and dust and blood and gore and horsies and lots of stuff!
-Campaign AI is challenging enough to be hard and entertaining, but not too hard that it will make you claw your eyes out.
-The reintroduction of the family tree!

All in all, this game is well worth it's asking price. I would have paid $90 AUS and still been happy with the product. Keep up the good work Creative Assembly!

The system requirements are definitely full of ♥♥♥♥.
This game is so poorly optimized compared to Rome II that I felt jipped after purchasing this game. I can BARELY manage 18fps on low settings with a Core 2 Duo, GTX750ti and 8gb of RAM, where-as I could run Rome II at 40-50FPS on max-high settings very smoothly.

I mostly bought this game for the Rise of Mordor mod; but the game itself is not good - Spend your money on Rome II, or even Shogun II which is one of the most amazing Total War games - and my favourite to date.

reviewText:
I voted positively for Attila, amidst a sea of thousands of negative reviews. I sympathise with a lot of the negative reviews, and I understand what they're talking about in their reviews. Though in my Opinion this game really isn't so bad that it deserves a negative review, and I really don't hate this title, I think it could be one of the better Total War Titles.

Though the AI is markably better than Rome II's AI, it's still not that smart... at all. My experience with rivercrossing battles and Town Battles is one of a slaughter. With a spear infantry core and basic ranged support can keep the most powerful enemy armies in check, unless the numbers are disproportionately against you. There are no tactics to try lower possible casualties, they just rush in at you. This slaughter is even worse if you have pike units, who cannot be beaten in melee, and occasionally cause scenes like in Rome II where they simply plough down large groups of charging enemies. The other battles seem much the same, with most City Siges won or lost at the walls with no battles in the streets. Its more a matter of numbers than anything at this point, with increasing the difficulty only making the units harder to beat, not making use of tactics.

However, Campaign map AI has improved. It raises its own well rounded and massive armies (The effects of which are apparantly of now consequence to the AI nation) and will attack and defend where required. They fight you where they can, and retreat where they don't have the numbers. You fight in the open, they sige you, they expand (Not really unless you use mods, otherwise they just burn down the whole world around them and create a dead zone around them with no neighbours.) However again, the AI nations seem impervious to huge ammounts of Squalor and apparantly have no budget. There are no political instabilities within their Nations themselves, and seem to suffer no setbacks when they lose their National Leaders or heirs.

Another small note is that Naval battles just seem to not exist or not be anywhere near as fun or intresting. The only navies that I tend to see are just generals transporting their troops across the seas. It does feel like it plays a very big side note in all of the game, unlike what it has been in all previous titles.

But regardless of all these things, I still have hours and hours of fun when I play Attila, and dont see these problems as thigns that can't be fixed in coming titles and improved upon.

reviewText:
A lot of people have bashed CA lately for their choices in marketing. But I will try to be as fair as I can be.
I AM a total war fan-boy. I own everything total war, and I will continue to do so - even though I most likely will wait for a 75% sale before buying any DLC.
To be frank, Attila is a great TW game. It all comes down to what you want to compare it to.
To me it is a clear single player upgrade to Rome 2. They have refined everything, and built upon what worked in Rome 2.
They have been keeping up with the weird tradition of adding DLC factions in small quantities. What would help them actually motivate this is if they kept on updating and patching the older DLC factions as well. It royally ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off that they started adding faction quest lines with additional content to the newer DLC factions, but ignored the first ones and just let them be. There is such a thing as bad DLCs at the moment.
From a MP standpoint the game is more stable than Rome 2, but from an online combat standpoint it's a bit disappointing. The maps are really detailed and a clear upgrade from any TW game before. But the unit balance is very icky at the moment. This is barely noticable in the SP experience though.

If you are looking for a singleplayer experience: 8,5/10
If you are looking for a multiplayer experience: 8,5/10
If you are looking for an online community without the campaign elements: 5/10

In short, if you are after a game where you wanna compete with other players, at the moment, you should be looking at Rome 2 instead of this one.

Review Title        Total War: ATTILA                Review Date        26th of February 2016                PC Release Date        17th of February 2015                Developer        The Creative Assembly                Publisher        Sega                Genre        Turn-based & real-time strategy                Series        Total War                Single Player        Yes                Multiplayer        Yes

Devo's Seal of Approval?:
Absolutely! Fans of real-time strategy games, turn-based strategy games, or both, should play this game. Despite this series' rocky history regarding polished experiences, Total War: ATTILA delivers a compeling experience. Coupled with a vibrant modding community and interesting downloadable campaigns in the form of DLC, this title should be held equal to the classics such as Rome: Total War and Medieval II: Total War; titles easily regarded as this series' pinacle.

PROS
The ability to field huge armies in real-time battles - I fought a battle with approximately 10,000 men seiging a fortified city without major performance drops on high- to maximum-settings
New game mechanics including Re-settlement and Political Intrigues,
A return of the family tree, also with new game mechanics allowing you to influence marriages, political support, decrees to office, assassinations, defamations...and the list goes on,
Individually tailoured national objectives which you can use to guide your conquest,
Addictive pseudo-RPG system for generals, characters and forces,
Amazingly detailed units, battle maps, and campaign maps,
A highly detailed and diverse range of settlement types represented on the real-time battle map,
Overall excellent graphics and performance,
CONS
Some campaigns have balancing issues. For example, Mercia, despite being described as Starting Challenge: Easy"

reviewText: Until recently, Empire: Total War was my favorite of the series. Attila brings to light a lot better aesthetics, as well as a whole new approach to the series. They made up for making Napoleon a mediocre game to making this game an absolute master piece. It's worth every cent, even at regular price, but I got my copy on sale. You can choose anywhere to fight from Spain to Pakistan, whether seige, land, or sea. I have my graphics options set to a lower version, and yet it still looks amazingly well. You can have large armies of up to 40 regiments as compared to the intial 20 in previous games in the series. All around in a brief summary, it's the best one, highly recommend it to anyone who likes the challenge this series has always offered,

reviewText:
Total War: Attila = Review

You'll love...

= The Huns and Attila are the most challenging threat in any TW game
- AI is more strategic oon the campaign and a little better in battles then in Rome II
- On the campaign, the factions, both in difficulty and position very drasticly
= Music is probably the best soundtrack since Shogun 2 ( dark, drums, apocalyptic)
= The Western Roman Empire is the hardest campaign in any TW game
- Expansive unit rosters, much more than in Rome II, though are sometimes repetitive
- The famil tree makes you care about characters again and the plitcial system helps with role-playing
- Horde system is incredibly well-designed with 10 building slots and a good pace of sack/razing, build, repeat

You may like or dislike...

- Razing, as it creates proinces owned by no one and gives atmosphere, but can lead to the map becoming too barren
- DLC, there is A LOT of it, though it, in my opinion, some of the best in the series
- Factions, in general are less diverse then in Rome II, as its moslty barbs, romans, and some desert units, instead of having gauls, britons, germanics, greeks, romans, etc.
- Probably the hardest TW to date, so its difficult to get into, but rewarding once you learn it
- Religion also returns, but outside of a small buff, doesn't play that big of a role, and the conversion percent of 35% is too steep


You'll hate...

- Multiplayer is identical to Rome II, with even less preset maps, making it one of the most barren in all TWs
- Politics is still a pain in the ♥♥♥ to manage, and is extremelly confusing and barely explained in the tutorial
- Germanic troops are everwhere, both in playable and non-playable factions

If you asked me to score it...

Overall: 8/10

It's not the best Total War game, but its definetly a great one, and despite some of its problems with rosters and a bare multiplayers, the challenging campaign with a varity of starting positions and playstyles, puts it pretty well up there on the list of best TW games.

reviewText:
Definitely better than Total War: Rome II but still with some flaws and annoyances.

Good:
+ graphics, very nice UI
+ beautiful and well designed campaign map, reasonable travel times
+ great atmosphere, faithful representation of the era filled with chaos and downfall
+ family tree, entertaining politics
+ overall quite well polished and balanced, no significant bugs

Bad:
- very annoying Huns respawning (kill one stack and the very next turn a new one spawns from nowhere, preferably in the middle of your empire razing your settlement during its first turn without any chance for you to defend the city)
- cities being razed so often that you usually feel more like a colonist than a conqueror
- stupid AI as usual (but beter than in TWR2)

So not bad. But Medieval 3 would be great.. Any hope CA? :-)

Just like Rome II, Attila is a great game for multiplayer battles.  Graphics are excellent.  Improvements as compared to Rome II include the following:
-Fire mechanics are impressive.
-Crossbows are introduced as well as axe infantry and neither of these are present in Rome II.  This adds more variety to the game.
-The game play is a little bit slower than Rome II, which is a good thing.  In Rome II the calvary charges came too fast and could deciminate archers before you have sufficient time to react.

The game is worse than Rome II in the following aspects:

Considering how easy it would be to fix this issue, it makes one wonder why they don't do it.

reviewText:
Total War: ATTILA
ATTILa is a very fun game for history nuts or just for strategically minded people in general. ATTIL, though hard to run, has stunning graphics and a great atsmopher in which you strive to  maintain your kingdom, but also to conquer other kingdoms.

Despite the reviews ATTILa is not bad game. Though not the best within the franchise it still is a fun and enjoyable game. The game brings back features from the previous Total War games and adds new features within comabat and diplomacy. There is mechanics that work well and there are some that don't. The ai in ATTILa is... special. At random moments the ai will just run back and forth wearing out there men and not attacking you. Sometimes though, the ai will do something smart and put you in tough positions w/ criticle outcomes.

If your a history nut then you'll apreciate this game w/o all of the mechanics, combat and diplomacy. The game allows you to play as the corrupted roman halfs, the barbarous Kingdoms, The persian empire, Great Migrators, and even the Huns w/ their legendary General ATTILA. Though there is much replayability to this is as you don't have to follow the historcle timeline and if you wanted to, could resotre rome to it's former glory by conquering the entire map!

The game has a thing w/ fire and destruction giving you the ability to raze a settlemen or catch one on w/ fire. ATTILA has great seiges, though are sometimes buggy, and well forged combat system making the battles more strategy then just brute force(although that works sometimes). The diplomacy aswell can have strategy to it aswell as the decisions you make carry impact to what could or could not happen.

However, the DLC for this game is horrible. The few good ones being the last roman campaing and the age of charlemagne. the rest just being silly cultures packs that add about 2 factions to game for 8$.

Overall this game is, though not perfect, enjoyable espicially if you love history. It offers alot, like the strategic battles and diplomatic decisions w/ historicle starting zones, but the ability to change the historicle timeline. It takes alot aswell though, making certain parts being buggy and laggy w/ glitches. I feel that this game has alot of potential. But 60% of the times, games live up to that potential. Sadly this game is the 40%, though it's still great, if could have been alot better.

Rating For Total War ATTILA:  7.8/10

The full review can be found on Start 2 Continue[start2continue.com].

Excerpt:

“The air was filled with smoke and blood.” There seems to be a lot of that in Creative Assembly‘s latest strategy title Total War: ATTILA, which–as you can imagine–takes place at the beginning of the end for the Roman Empire.

While you still have to buy the actual blood effects through silly DLC packs (I’ll get to that a bit later), ATTILA improves upon Rome II‘s engine and gameplay mechanics, adding more depth to the strategic map with scorched earth, mass migration, and the fertility of your provinces’ lands.

[...]

If the marauding hordes, crippling famine, and the implosion of Western Rome and its subsequent power vacuum weren’t enough, you now have to worry about enemies from within your faction as well. Polishing up Rome II‘s original dynasty system (or lack thereof), the nobles of your house and faction play important roles as governors, generals, and councillors, each position granting its own factional and personal bonuses. Without loyal retainers, your doomed to civil war–which, in its own way, can be played to your favor, expunging political rivals who bark louder than they can bite.

reviewText:
Total War: Attila is arguably the anti-thesis to Rome 2. It enjoyed a stable launch, is extremely difficult, places a much greater value on specific characters, and it’s as un-optimized as the Red Army in Afghanistan. The game itself takes place in Late Antiquity and sees the player tasked with either defending their already pre-existing empire (East/West Roman and Sassanid) or attempting to topple the giants as one of the smaller barbarian or dessert peoples. So the question is, will you attempt to save civilization? Or destroy it? And… well… is the game even any good?

To answer that last question quickly, yes the game is very good, and difficult, extremely difficult. However, instead of continuing with a normal review, I will instead give you guys an amusing story.

Step 1.) Play as WRE
Step 2.) Get owned
Step 3.) Try again
Step 4.) Lose
Step 5.) Try again
Step 6.) Marry away 17 year old girl to 55 year old man for money (Roma Invicta!)
Step 7.) Our Emperor has at least 7 illegitimate children (Staph man!)
Step 8.) Kill the Batman
Step 8.) Heir to throne gets an attribute called “flaccid”, he doesn’t have any kids…..
Step 9.) Fight more wars, lose Africa
Step 10.) 3 wars and two plagues later, family is all dead, have to bring in new guy
Step 11.) Go public with an IPO of $55.
Step 12.) Stock goes up, shareholder very pleased
Step 13.) Board wants result, so I try harder
Step 14.) Board says they are not pleased and fire me, something about unethical
Step 15.) Say NO, I am an artist!
Step 16.) Counter invade Gaul
Step 17.) Burn down everything!
Step 18.) End up killing Girl I sold off earlier on accident (such is life in the zone)
Step 19.) Get Owned by Attila and never-ending Doomstacks of Huns….

And that’s really what you need to know about Total War: Attila. Like all TW games it has faults, like dumb(ish) AI and enough DLC to bankrupt a Super PAC. But what Attila does right, is enough to make up for its admittedly smaller number of mistakes when compared to Rome 2.

reviewText:
It seems Creative Assembly has been a hotbed of discontent recently and this may be downrated simply because it's a recommendation for the game, I just hope you will treat this review based on its merits instead. Thank you

This is more of an introduction to the game and my opinions instead of a 'review'. I don't really have any method to my madness, I just start writing about what comes to mind first, I hope you enjoy the read!

Factions
You can play as the rapidly declining Roman factions who start with a large number of regions but very little military power. Oh, did I mention that they are surrounded by nomadic factions (some hostile) trying to flee west to get away from the rampaging Huns? You can also play as the Huns (Attila) conquering everything in your path.  Alternatively, you can choose one of the fairly weak (by comparison) nomadic factions who are the first factions the Hun's come across. As the Visigoth's, I made for the sea and travelled to Spain to start my empire.

AI
I feel the AI has been significantly improved over Rome 2, I'd say it's the best it's ever been. In battle it's aggressive, so don't expect them to sit down until your ranged units use up all of their ammo, and they will make you charge them if they have a ranged advantage. In sieges I haven't had the AI mess up allowing me to exploit them once yet (an old common issue),  it's always on the move and you'll need to be on your toes to stop them from flanking you.

On the campaign map however, the AI still acts strangely sometimes. I've had a faction declare war on me, send an army just outside of one of my ports and kept it there for a few turns only to beg for peace, and then brought the units in closer to my port the next turn. I can't expect a perfect AI, but it's pretty silly to see sometimes.

Family
The family system is more involved than it was in, say Medieval 2, but it's not anything special. It's a battle within your  faction, trying to gain total power over it.  Though the more power you gain the more corruption you'll face (which is a loss of income and public order). There are certain events that can pop up, but it's all based on chance and using up your character's 'influence' and there's not much beyond that.  It's very basic and feels like a chore at times. I'd love to see a more complex and rewarding family system in a future game.

Diplomacy
Having played Medieval 2, Empire, Napoleon and Shogun 2 in the recent past I have to say Attila's diplomacy is also the best it's ever been. I've never had a friendly nation declare war on me nor had a hostile factions trade with me unless I bribed them with something. You have to build up your reputation with factions by starting with a non-aggression pact which will build positive relations with them over time, though nothing is ever a guarantee. A lot of factors go into this, such as your deals or wars with their enemies or friends. There are also religious factors and even something akin to jealousy comes into play. These have been in the TW games for a while now,  but everything seems to be fully explained making it helpful for figuring out how to overcome certain obstacles.

Agents
Agent's are as helpful as ever. The name's vary between factions, but break down to: Assassin, Priest and Champion. The assassin pokes holes in and poison people, introduces fire to buildings and can improve the black market in their deployed region. The Priest spreads religion and improves public order in friendly regions, can lower public order in an enemy's, and can increase the integrity of an army. The Champion can train your troops in an army, scout out areas and can incite unrest in enemy lands. It's really nice to see the agent's having more varied roles.

Armies / Units
The number of units is about on par with normal Total War games, the Visigoths for example, have ~36 different units. In Medieval 2, England has ~35 units. You have your spearmen, swordsmen, skirmishers, archers, calvary and siege engines as you'd expect, but there are different flavor's of each type. For example, there are armored swordsmen units with high armor and defense values though have slower movement speeds and mediocre charge bonus values making them perfect for head on fights. Then, there are lightly armored, fast, 'light infantry' with high charge and attack values making them perfect for flanking but s bad choice for a prolonged engagement due to the poor armor and defense values.

Cavalry, while not quite as numerous as the infantry, are quite varied too. Some just have swords and shields and are a solid mobile unit that can stay in a fight for quite a while. Others have spears and are a great to counter to enemy calvary and have high charge values but generally lower armor and defense values so keeping them engaged is a poor idea (cycle charge!). There are also archer and javelin skirmisher cavalry as well making them very well rounded units.

Unit growth
You start out with being able to recruit tier 1 units and through research unlock higher tier units which are basically advanced versions with increased stats and sometimes new skills. When you research a new tech that unlocks replacements it will allow you to retrain your obsolete units, but retraining has a cost and the new units will have an increased upkeep cost as well. I really enjoyed this as I was being introduced to new units throughout the campaign and my old units kept their ranks as they evolved into something new. If you remember Rome 1 & 2 with the Marian reforms which were pretty much a downgrade at worst and a side grade at best.. this is nothing like that. There are no downsides to it besides the initial cost and upkeep.

A better building builder
In Rome 2, before the Emperor's Edition update, the building management was a mess to say the least. Buildings and their advantages (and disadvantages) were poorly explained and I had a very hard time figuring out what would be best to build. Maybe I was just too dumb before, but in Attila can form a plan on how I want to set up certain regions very easily. For example I've set up one region for recruiting solders so it would give bonuses to their starting rank, stats and morale. In another region I set it up to maximize agricultural income. I'll have a region in a central area set up to reduce squalor and spread religion and increase public order in it's surrounding regions. If you want to get as much out of these regions as possible you'll need to take some time to plan but it's worth it!

In brief
So, do I like this game? Yes and I'd recommend it to any fan of the series and to strategy fans in general. It isn't my favorite in the series (due to the time period), but I'd say that this is the best game from a technical standpoint. It runs great with a 4 year old rig with everything on max. The UI is nice to look at and easy to use. The combat feels great and rewards tactics over mindless fast clicking, and the sieges feel intense again. The building system is easy to understand and should help you plan out your buildings better than before. The units are varied enough from faction to faction making different playthroughs feel quite different by having different army compositions as well as the starting locations. The graphics and sound are wonderful as you'd expect. I can't think of many bad things to say about the game to be honest. You can't go wrong with buying this on one of the frequent sales where it's around $10.

Thank you for reading this, I hope I was of some help
Feedback is always appreciated as long as it's civil

reviewText:
I don't recommend paying full price for this game.

The real title should be ATTILA: TOTAL DLC.

Just to put things in perspective, you have to pay $5 for a 'Gore pack' in order to see blood in this game...

To be completely honest, this game is fun, and they've improved the battle system and campaign map over previous TW games. However... I just can't recommend anyone support CA's increasingly greedy anti-consumer practices by buying this game at full price.

When you buy this game, about half the content (factions, campaigns, world maps, etc.) is immediately behind DLC pay walls. Looking through the menu, this game feels like a free-to-pay mobile app, with the amount of content you have to purchase separately. Just to

On top of that, CA has been refusing to listen to it's fan base on numerous issues. Fans have been asking for multiplayer grand campaigns (more than two players) since Medieval 1, and while CA promised it would be in 'Empire', that turned out to be a lie. CA also has a history of launching terrible products and not addressing it (look up Rome 2 Fiasco).

To be fair, there is fun to be had in this game. But if I didn't get it at 75% off, I would be disappointed.

I personally will not pay full price for anything from Creative Assembly.

Attila obviously should have been Rome 2 DLC.  Charlemagne has almost as many changes as Attila did and it's $15.

reviewText:
I love this game.
I love it so much that bought a whole new computer just for it.
And it still runs like crap.

Honestly this is a good game, and I know it's odd to give a bad review to a game you like, but when you're really engrossed in a campaign and it starts taking double the ammount of time it did in the beginning to end a turn, it's beyond frustrating.

I overlooked this when the game was newer. I figured it was like Rome II, that the developers would gradually make it run vastly better over the course of a number of patches, but here we are a year later and no better off despite lots of DLC patches. I don't actually mind the DLC, I feel like it actually adds something to the game, but when you're only making DLC instead of the patches to make the game run tolerably well, it's clear your priorities are wrong.

Don't get me wrong. There's a lot ot enjoy here. The siege escalation feature is one of my favorite things ever in a total war game, and the graphics, if you can turn them up, are breathtaking. In so many ways this game feels like What Rome II promised us in that very misleading carthage demo so long ago, but unless you have a computer made by in the workshop of the gods of technology, all of the fun of this game will just feel like a taunt, reminding you of what you're missing out on.

reviewText:
Really great game, far better than Rome II's launch. The whole mood is way different, which I think is the biggest improvement for me over Rome II.  In Rome it felt like each battle was meaningless; you were probably going to win, and even if you didn't, the only consequence was losing out on some meaningless conquest in the corner of the world.

In Attila, it is entirely different. Playing as the Eastern Romans, if you do not meet the enemy in the field and win, the barbarians will raze and pillage your cities. You are not fighting for glory, you are fighting for survival. I get nervous for each outnumbered battle I fight, because I know that if I lose, I am opening up my heartland to irrevirsible destruction.

So far the only bugs I have experienced involve pathfinding issues, which occurred when a fortress spawned on a slope, and despite the walls being buried underground, I could still not send units over them. However, this seems like a minor issue to me.

On the optimization side, I have experienced no problems whatsoever with my year-old graphics card. I'm pretty sure that all the people complaining about crashes/low framerates are too ignorant to update their drivers, so... sucks to them?

All and all a great game, and a worthy contender for being my favorite Total War game yet!

reviewText:
An good improvement on Rome 2, it has to be said. This game is what Napoleon was to Empire.

Whilst it made me sick to see so much DLC at the start, it has been a while since any has been released which is good news.
I was very happy to see Blood and Burning is a lot cheaper than Rome 2, I would also say it's better than Rom 2's blood and gore pack, I just hope they will make an option to make the blood stains permanent instead of quickly fading.

Ok, so for the main game...
This game is horrible to run on my current PC which should be more than capeable of running this at at least 40-50 FPS, I get FPS drops on the main screen, not even in game. Gameplay on the other hand is good and I can maintain a good FPS, even in chaotic battles, I just don't think SEGA and CA did enough to optimize this game at all. During the campaign the game crashes after perhaps as little as 30 minutes playing for no reason. This happened in Rome 2 as well, although that was fixed in patch 15.

Saying this, what little I do get to play of my campaigns in between crashes and me raging, the game is good. Never too easy like in Rome 2, the AI is responsive and generally adapts well to situations in battle, and example of this was when I attacked an enemy camp, they lacked the men to block up all entry points to the camp, I also lacked the men to attack through each one, so they just pinned me at the entry points I went for and kept a unit in reserve to block off any other one I tried to attack. I did win, purely because of my numbers though.

I love spreadable fire, makes the battle map feel more interactive and dynamic.

I also like the fact when I attack cities and leave them for a few turns, they start to collapse, it was the only thing which allowed my small Saxon army to attack a poorly manned but formidable Rome.

The the units are good, for once they actually vary, unlike Rome 2 where any faction from a particular region was almost identical in terms of unit roster.
It's not as good as Rome 1 where every faction is different, but it's a start.

Happy to see a return of the family tree.

reviewText:
Total War: Attila is to Rome II what Napoleon Total War was to Empire: it is a more polished, better optimized version of a previous game set in a time period that is close enough in proximity to make the style of warfare (and therefore gameplay) similar, but far enough away to add new mechanics that do not look suspicious or out of place. If Rome II is about building an Empire, Attila is about surviving an onslaught of calamity or causing it, depending on what side of the wall you are on.

The Good:
The Setting...
Attila is set during a time period of terror and dispair. Themes such as disease, war, famine, loss of hope, and the failings of civilization are ever present. The game is not fair, nor does it pretend to be. I can say honestly without reservation that when you play Attila, you are playing a game where the board is stacked against you and you are always one step behind its devilish designs. Sometimes, the only option is to make the best out of a bad situation and soldier on. Other times, the only option is to start the game over after being systemically dismantled. The game is engaging however, and has a lot more character than previous total war titles with in game cinematics telling the tale of Attilas rise and fall as the scourge of God. This game is about survival first and foremost: conquest or glory takes a back seat. The music is also leaps and bounds better than Rome II and sets the mood.
The Gameplay...
The gameplay both on the campaign map and in battles is quite good. It is arguably what Rome II should have been at launch. Unlike Rome II, I play this game absent any mods and I find the AI is punishing and as devious as ever. Seiges and playing on the defensive has never been so fun in a total war game since Shogun 2. Playing on the offensive is simply not an option for several factions until you are 100 + turns in as your units simply do not have the capabilities (the Romans). For other factions, offence is THE ONLY option. This means that the game has huge replayability: the game will play differently everytime you play as a new faction. With so many factions to choose from, you will be playing this game for a long time. Add in the Age of Charlamagne DLC, and you will be playing even longer. However, as mentioned above, Attila is a game where paranoid strategists will feel right at home because the game is stacked against you. It is not fair, and you will lose...a lot. But like games such as XCOM, sometimes getting pummelled is just part of the fun. You will lose a campaign 150 turns in and still be amazed with how epic it all was. New gameplay mechanics like a family tree, sanitation, hordes, governors, and my personal favourite, the ability to set fire to settlements while in battle are a delight.
The Grapĥics...
The game looks amazing and is optimized far better than Rome II. Running this on max graphics settings is quite a sight to behold. The new settlement razing mechanic both in the campaign map and in battle look amazing. It feels like you are there, fighting in Rome with the entire city burning around you, and that is pretty sweet. The graphics in this game are what was promised in Rome II at launch...incredible. There is not much else to say on the matter. The game is beautiful.
The Challenge...
Playing as Western Rome is the most satisfying but brutally hard game of total war I have ever played. And I loved every second of it.
The Bad:
Preferences...
This game is not a traditional total war game. I personally view this in the games favour as I like the change of direction, but this is something that divided many fans. It is less of a historical what if simulator and more of a historical survival simulator.
Razing...
By the end of the game almost the entirety of the map will be a pile of burnt tinders. This makes expansion an expensive proposition late game, as it takes on average, 10,000 gold to rebuild a minor settlement. This makes the legendary victories time consuming to achieve more than challenging. You will often get a minor victory and find yourself in a wasteland with no other factions left, and just call it quits rather than mash end turn over and over to save to rebuild. I like the razing mechanic but wish the AI used it a bit less zealously. That said, razing settlement after settlement as Attila is a blast.
Bar Bar...$$...
Barbarian Factions must spend so much gold to transform roman settlements into their own that it is unreasonable. Again, this acts as a barrier to rapid expansion, and forces you to sit back, turtle, and save money more than I would like.

Conclusion: Buy when on sale with Age of Charlamagne expansion. Do not buy any of the other DLC, as it is not worth the $$. Buy instead of Warhammer TW.
